title: guyanese indigenous tribes hold key unprecedented wealth worlds
story: Kicking up clouds of red dust and scattering flocks of wild ibis, Guy Fredricks guns his Honda motorbike over the dirt tracks of the Rupununi savannah in southern Guyana.Election season is a busy time for a toshao, the chiefs of Guyana’s indigenous Amerindian villages. For Mr Fredricks there are errands to be run, gifts to be delivered and political news to be relayed. On March 2 the former British colony, South America’s only English speaking country, will hold its most important general election in a generation. Whoever wins will preside over the first revenues from a colossal offshore oil project set to radically transform the tiny country's fortunes.With the main parties equally matched, the votes of the country’s Amerindian minority could be crucial for victory.  “We make the difference in the election,” says Mr Fredricks. “Recently we have seen a lot of development. Our requests for assistance have been coming through, but will that happen after the elections?”The three villages Mr Fredricks represents - totalling 700 members of the Macushi people - lie at the heart of a 5,000 square mile region of grasslands. The area is separated from the coastal capital, Georgetown, by 500 kilometres of pristine rainforest populated by giant anteaters, 40-stone anacondas and monkey-eating harpy eagles.The region is famously remote. When a bruised and penitent Evelyn Waugh visited in 1932 while escaping a collapsing marriage, he used the savannah and region and surrounding jungles as the setting for the nightmarish ending of A Handful of Dust. In his notes he described the local parish of St Ignatius “as lonely an outpost of religion as you could find anywhere.”Outside of campaigning season, the Macushi – along with the nearby Wapishana and Wai-Wai tribes – are largely neglected by the state.Following the decline of the cattle ranching and latex industries, many inhabitants rely on subsistence agriculture and the tiny eco-tourism industry.Three quarters of inhabitants live in poverty, compared to a national average of 36 per cent.Nine out of ten Guyanese live on the country’s Caribbean coast, once home to vast sugar estates worked first by slaves and then indentured labour from the Indian subcontinent.Those waves of immigration has left the population of 778,000 almost evenly split between Guyanese of African and East Indian ancestry.With each group expected to vote along ethnic lines, the backing of indigenous voters, who make up 10 per cent of the population, is the key to victory.The stakes have never been higher. Guyana is on the brink of becoming filthily, incomparably rich. A few days before Christmas the first oil began to flow from the depths of ExxonMobil’s giant Liza 1 offshore field, the first of a series of oil projects that promise to transform Guyana’s economic destiny.Early estimates say the oil will earn Guyana’s government over $120 billion in royalties and taxes, pushing up its GDP by 86 per cent in 2020 alone.In Georgetown, however, there is little sign of such riches. The city’s once-grand timber architecture creaks and crumbles in the Caribbean climate. The roadside waterways clog with litter.So far the main benefits of the boom have been landowners, who have sold riverside and coastal terrains to shore bases for the oil industry and property developers who can charge New York City prices for houses in gated communities.A sense of pessimism prevails. “We’ve been told Guyana would be a rich country before, first with sugrar, then with bauxite, then with gold, yet our country remains poor” says Jared Kissoon, an agribusiness entrepreneur. “People are sceptical about how politicians will manage the money and whether that the oil wealth with filter down to where it is needed.”International experts share the concern that the country could succumb to the resource curse, whereby immense natural resource riches leads to worse economic and developmental outcomes.Its neighbour to the west, Venezuela, has seen economic collapse and the establishment of authoritarian rule despite sitting on top of the world’s largest oil reserves.“We are already seeing the effects of the resource curse in Guyana,” says Marla Dukharan, a Trinidadian economist with a regional focus. “There is serious – and wide – institutional weakness, a lack of transparency and rising levels of corruption.”The government has made positive steps, she concedes, through the establishment of a sovereign wealth fund aimed at saving and invested oil funds for benefit future generations and the development of a national development strategy focused on green growth and investing in human capital.Winston Jordan, the finance minister, says that of the $300 million the government expects to earn from ExxonMobil’s oil production in 2020, roughly half will be saved in the fund and half made available for spending.“This is not a slush fund, we have strict rules on what can be drawn down by the government,” he says. “Oil has been a saviour for the economy.”Guyanese politics are already balanced on the tiniest margins. In 2015 the People’s National Congress party (PNC), which draws its support from Afro-Guyanese voters  – in coalition with a smaller party – won 33 of the country’s 65 national assembly seats but, following the defection of one its members, it subsequently lost a no confidence vote in December 2018.That should have led to a general election within 90 days but a protracted legal debate pushed the date back until 2020, to the frustration of many voters.The opposition People’s Progressive Party (PPP) – and its East Indian base – are emboldened, but the emergence of a new party with indigenous rights at the centre of its campaign strategy, has created the prospect of a hung parliament with the new party as potential kingmakers.“The traditional parties use indigenous votes to get into office and then marginalize the very same people,” says Lenox Shuman, a former toshao and presidential candidate for the newly-formed Liberty &amp Justice Party (LJP).“They delay the awarding of indigenous land rights, give timber and mining licenses to their political allies and do nothing to prevent the daily incursion of hunters who slaughter animals and destroy livelihoods.” The LJIP have a real chance of winning a handful of seats in indigenous majority regions, according to Denis Chabol, a journalist and political commentator.Mr Shuman – who renounced his dual Canadian citizenship in order to run for office – has refused the overtures of both main parties to enter into coalition but says if his party win seats in parliament he will propose legislation allowing for the establishment of post-election coalitions, potentially putting his party in the position of kingmakers.Then the LJP will target the oil industry, with Mr Shuman promising to table legislature to renegotiate oil contracts, which many Guyanese believe are overly generous to foreign companies.A report by Global Witness released this week alleges that ExxonMobil’s “exploitative deal” in Guyana has deprived the country and its citizens of up to $55 billion. The government and Exxon deny the claims.“It is very difficult to see how the oil revenues will be governed with integrity and integrity and in the best interest of the people,” Mr Shuman says. “The international oil companies have conspired with the politicians to undermine the sovereignty of Guyana.”Guyana’s government “views the report as a cunning and calculated attack on a sovereign state with a duly elected government mere weeks before an election.”“We have complied with applicable laws at each step of the exploration, appraisal and development stages, anything to the contrary is baseless and without merit,”  Exxon said in an email to Bloomberg.In Georgetown, Julian McEwan, wipes down the long wooden bar of his guesthouse, a popular watering hole for PNC members. With demand for accommodation surging, he is about to add another floor of rooms upstairs.A close vote and a legal challenge from the losing party could lead to a period of limbo and slowed investment. “In Guyana the races live in harmony,” he says with a pause, “until election time.”More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: pressure health chiefs british virus super spreader
story: Health officials are under pressure to release details of the movements of a British coronavirus “super spreader” - amid fears the virus is far more contagious than was thought.The unnamed businessman, who contracted the virus in Singapore, is now known to have infected at least seven fellow Britons in a French ski resort, before returning home to Brighton, falling ill some some five days later.Those he infected include the fourth person to have contracted the disease in the UK and patients in Spain and France, all of whom were believed to have been with the 'super spreader' in France.But health authorities have refused to provide any details of the man’s movements during the five days he spent in the UK before showing symptoms - all that is known is that he spent two hours in a local pub the night before finally succumbing to the illness.On Sunday, it emerged that the man travelled back by Easyjet from Geneva to Gatwick on the 6.50pm flight on January 28th. The budget airline said it was notified by PHE on the evening of Thursday 6th. PHE said all passengers sitting near the man had been contacted and given advice. In a statement, Easyjet said it had been notified by the public health authority that a customer who had recently travelled on one of its flights has since been diagnosed with the Coronavirus.Public Health England is contacting all customers on the flight which was flight EZS8481 from Geneva to London Gatwick on 28 January, to provide guidance in line with procedures.  As the customer was not experiencing any symptoms, the risk to others on board the flight is very low.We remain in contact with the public health authorities and are following their guidance. The health and wellbeing of our passengers and crew is the airline’s highest priority. All of the crew who operated have been advised to monitor themselves for a 14 day period since the flight in line with Public Health England advice. Note this happened 12 days ago and none are displaying any symptoms.”On Sunday night scientists warned that medics may be “flying blind” in the war on coronavirus, amid growing evidence that it could be passed on long before symptoms show.Their warnings came as Public Health England (PHE) came under increasing fire for refusing to provide any information about the whereabouts of the “superspreader” during the period when he was likely to have been infectious.Health officials say they are tracking anyone who was within two metres of him for more than 15 minutes in the two weeks before his diagnosis, including those on the flight with him.They say those who have not been have not been contacted as a close contact, do not need to take any action. But the stance is coming under question, amid concerns that the virus appears to be far more contagious that was first thought.The middle-aged man contracted the virus during a company conference run by Servomex Gas, in Singapore, before flying to the Alps for a four-day break with friends. He is understood to have displayed no symptoms as he spent time in the resort of Contamines-Montjoie in the French Alps, before flying home on January 28. During the short break, he infected seven people, including environmental consultant Bob Saynor, 48, and his nine-year-old son. Two of the cases were only identified on Sunday one after flying back to his home near Palma in Majorca and the other having returned to London.Mrs Saynor's wife Catriona is now in a UK hospital, though it is not clear if she is the latest case to be diagnosed in Britain.The ski resort at the centre of the outbreak is now in lock-down.It was not until February 2 - five days after his return -  that the businessman fell ill, alerting the NHS which treated him in isolation at Royal Sussex Hospital, before transferring him to London for specialist treatment. He had felt well enough to visit his local pub before succumbing to the illness, spending two hours at The Grenadier in Hove last Saturday evening, February 1.Five members of staff working that night have been told to “self-isolate,” while a student at the nearby Portslade Aldridge Community Academy, who is also understood to have had contact with the man, has been advised to remain in isolation for two weeks. His journey is outlined here:Prof Richard Tedder, Visiting Professor in Medical Virology, Imperial College London, said the fact that the virus might have been passed on by a person without symptoms suggested the outbreak could be worse than SARS, and turn into a pandemic. Given current testing methods, “we are truly flying blind if it is the case that the coronavirus can be transmitted by those without symptoms,” he said. Brighton residents expressed anger at the refusal of the authorities to provide more information. Valerie Painter, a regular patient at the Royal Sussex County Hospital, said: The population of Brighton and Hove is very densely populated. We are living cheek by jowl in tiny streets close together,” she said. “Where has this person been on the buses and trains? What kind of tracing are the authorities doing?A spokesman for PHE said: “We are contacting people who were in close contact with any of the cases that have been confirmed in the UK, to provide them with health advice. We are working closely with the French authorities.PHE said it would not release patient identifiable information, such as a timeline of movements about any inidual who is part of a public health investigation.The new cases came as a second and final plane carrying British citizens evacuated from the Chinese city of Wuhan landed in Oxfordshire.The flight, with more than 200 people on board, including some foreign nationals, arrived at RAF Brize Norton shortly before 7.30am on Sunday, taking evacuees to a conference centre in Milton Keynes. The death toll in China from the virus now stands at 904, surpassing the number of Sars fatalities in 2002-2003.More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: garden sustainable space how to build tips tricks climate 20 pledges
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.This year, Chris Riotta is growing his own fruit and vegetables – in the middle of New York CityWhether you’re working with a few feet of space in a community vegetable patch, or have 65 acres of luscious foliage on a sprawling estate (looking at you, Oprah Winfrey), the first step to building a sustainable garden is mapping out a vision of your intentions.Each year before planting my own vegetable patch, I draw out an image of the garden I hope to build, indicating where each plant should go based on available sunlight and shading.&nbspI’m currently planning to build the largest garden I’ve ever grown, while working to harvest one-third of my annual vegetable consumption directly from my backyard, as part of my mission for The Independent’s 20&nbspPledges&nbspfor 2020 initiative. While mapping out the garden, I put together a few tips and tricks to help get you started on your own sustainable vegetable patch.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesPlan out where to place your&nbspplantsRoot to fruit: How to join the ethical food revolutionI like to plant crops that grow on vines (think: cucumbers and cherry tomatoes) in small groups, as close to a fence as possible so they scale upwards, while giving other plants that will likely grow much larger a separate space off to the side. That way, I can still walk by and tend to the crops growing up the fence, no matter how big the other plants off to the side eventually grow.&nbspThis also works with smaller plots of soil like community garden space: keep clusters of similar plants in the same tight groups, and don’t worry so much about spacing. With some proper TLC, plants usually find their way around each other in the dirt.&nbspSeeds can always begin growing indoors ahead of the season around the time you lay out your soil, which will provide you with plenty of time to start growing your crops in a stable environment. Some farmers will recommend you transport these seeds to your garden based on the location of the moon, but since I don’t have time for all that, I simply give the soil a good rinse of water for a week before transporting or planting anything in my garden.Study your plotBefore stepping into that dirt, it’s important to study your space and gain an understanding of how many hours of sunlight you’re working with and what kind of plants grow well in the region. Most will require about eight hours of sun, but if you’re in a shaded area and can only get six, that should still work, as many plants favour partial shade and only require about four hours of direct sunlight.&nbspGetting a head start on laying out the groundwork for your garden will help it produce sustainable harvests that last throughout the summer months – and then some. You can look up the last frost date in your region here.&nbspI tend to lay out my organic soil exactly where I plant to grow my garden about six weeks before this date.&nbspCreated with Sketch.Back to our roots: Warming winter vegetables recipes Show all 2Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Maximise your spaceIt’s also just as important to consider ways to maximise the space while gardening. Vertical garden walls can be purchased or made easily in DIY projects, allowing plants to grow above each other rather than spread out over a small space.&nbspOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailLastly, don’t be afraid to plant intensively. Most crops only need a few inches of space for their roots to grow: things like peppers, tomatoes, broccoli and kale can all grow much closer together than most people think. I tend to believe that crops grow better when they’re in close, clustered mixes of similar plants, but that’s just my unprofessional semi-gardening enthusiast opinion.Transplant the seeds to your garden once its warm enough for them to survive in an outdoor climate, but only when the seeds are busting out of their trays or starter pots. The seeds should look vibrant and almost too big for their trays by the time they are brought to the garden for planting.&nbspI tend to believe the first moments catering to a garden and each inidual plant are some of the most important in a life cycle the only way a garden will produce healthy crops is with tender love and care during its birth. title: birds of prey marvel opening weekend earnings dc universe
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The highly anticipated Harley Quinn superhero film disappoints with only $33.2m (£25.7m) at the box officeThe $33.2m (£25.7m) opening for Birds of Prey marks the lowest so far for a DC Comics title. Prior to this, the lowest was Shazam! which reached $53.5m ($41.4m).Cathy Yan’s highly-anticipated Birds of Prey cost around $80m&nbsp(£62m)&nbspto make and was projected to take $45m (£34.8m) to $55m ($42.6m) at the box office.&nbspThe opening is quite shocking when you consider that Warner Bros. had little competition from other films this weekend and released the title on over 4,200 screens. That’s a record-breaker for the month of February. Even more than Marvel opened Black Panther on back in 2018.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesCreated with Sketch. Show all 34Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.134 34. Ciaran Hinds as Steppenwolf (Justice League)We were so distracted by the bad jokes and Henry Cavill’s computer generated upper lip that it’s easy to forget that the Justice League faced off against a horned CGI muscle man voiced by Ciaran Hinds. So bad it effectively got everyone but Gal Gadot dumped from the franchise. (AW)234 33. Mark Pillow as Nuclear Man (Superman IV: The Quest for Peace)Presumably hired because fellow “foreign, unconvincing muscle-man” Dolph Lundgren wasn’t available, Mark Pillow made for one of the worst DC movie villains. To be fair to him, Superman IV: The Quest for Peace is a famously abysmal film, but his Nuclear Man – a villain so blandly nefarious even his name feels like it came about via 30 seconds of brainstorming – doesn’t help matters. (AW)334 32. Cara Delevingne as EnchantressJune Moone (Suicide Squad)It’s not been plain sailing swapping the catwalk for the big screen for this aristocratic supermodel-turned-actor, specifically with her role in this puerile comic book film. She plays June Moone, an archeological boffin transformed into a bikini-clad witch by some haunted dust. The film got devastatingly bad reviews, despite doing well at the box office. It may well be a performance Delevingne would like to forget. (CC)434 31. David Thewlis as Ares (Wonder Woman)The one area of Wonder Woman we don’t like to talk about is its villain, as his appearance in the film’s final act turns a smart and funny movie into one just like all the others – namely with two superpowered beings throwing things at each other. (AW)534 30. Patrick Wilson as Ocean Master (Aquaman)It was always going to be tricky to make much of an impression in a movie in which Amber Heard, sporting an enormous red wig, catapults her way into underwater battle riding a dolphin. Which might explain why Patrick Wilson, playing Aquaman’s dastardly half-brother Orm, has fallen so rapidly out of memory. (AW)634 29. Faye Dunaway as Selena (Supergirl)The doomed Supergirl movie is a living testament to how badly Mommie Dearest impacted the career of Faye Dunaway, with her turn as a witchy supervillain with a dangerous love spell at her disposal secretly the nadir of her Eighties career. She may nail a certain level of camp here, whether deliberate or not, but Dunaway is certainly no good – it’s no surprise she was awarded a Razzie for her performance. (AW)734 28. Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor (Superman Returns)A big gulp in 2019 for obvious reasons, but also pretty regretful because it's an incredibly dull performance from an actor who was, whether we like to admit it or not, masterful at playing villains in his prime. Here, however, Spacey is just a snooze. (AW)834 27. Yahya Abdul-Mahteen III as Black Manta (Aquaman)About as threatening as a Power Rangers villain and just as stupid-looking, Aquaman's recurring nemesis is more a perpetual irritant than someone particularly enjoyable to watch. (AW)934 26. Liam Neeson as Ra's al Ghul (Batman Begins)Ra's al Ghul, or The Demon's Head in Arabic, jumped on the climate activism bandwagon nice and early. For him, the human race is a cancer poisoning the Earth, and he wants to eliminate people to save the world from environmental disaster. Neeson played the villain so well because he really believed in him. “It was quite a good argument he comes up with,” the actor said. Terrifying. (EH)1034 25. Arnold Schwarzenegger as Mr Freeze (Batman &amp Robin)Arnold Schwarzenegger wasn't so much playing Mr Freeze in Batman &amp Robin as he was The Pun King, few surviving his merciless deployment of woeful gags. Schwarzenegger is by no means good here, but he's absolutely captivating nonetheless. (AW)1134 24. Sharon Stone as Laurel Hedare (Catwoman)Only one of the worst DC villains because her evil plot was to poison Gotham City via killer face cream, Laurel Hedare at least allowed Sharon Stone to be devious, slinky and cartoonish for the first time since Basic Instinct. It's a very minor victory, though. (AW)1234 23. Jared Leto as Joker (Suicide Squad)It would be easy to pity Jared Leto, who was always going to be compared to the late Heath Ledger’s transcendent portrayal of the Joker in Christopher Nolan’s The Dark Knight, if it weren’t for how much hype he built up before Suicide Squad was even released. There were the tattoos, his green hair, a shiny grill in his mouth, and a ludicrous number of articles about his supposed bad behaviour on set. So it was downright embarrassing when it turned out Joker wasn’t even the lead villain in the movie, and instead just an annoyance who turns up to mock the lead cast every now and then. (RO)1334 22. Marion Cotillard as Miranda Tate (The Dark Knight Rises)Although many will purely remember Cotillard’s performance in The Dark Knight Rises for that awfully awkward death scene, she was great in the rest of the movie. She played one of Batman’s most interesting female adversaries with a slyness and a deception that was mysteriously alluring and effective. (EH)1434 21. Michael Shannon as General Zod (Man of Steel)The kind of role Shannon could play in his sleep, his General Zod is more angsty and human than his live-action predecessors playing the same character, but harmed by the relentlessly dank surroundings of Zack Snyder’s film. He’s also saddled with the most unflattering haircut in all of DC movie history, which couldn’t have helped. (AW)1534 20. Tom Hardy as Bane (The Dark Knight Rises)1634 19. Burgess Meredith as The Penguin (Batman 1966)Entirely unsubtle work from Meredith here, the actor grinding his teeth and chewing on the end of a large, thin cigarette to emphasise the Penguin’s dastardly villainy. But it’s a lot of fun to behold nonetheless. (AW)1734 18. Gene Hackman as Lex Luthor (Superman)The Oscar-winning actor was easily the most fun incarnation of Lex Luthor when he was cast in the 1978 Superman. As the hero’s arch nemesis, his light-hearted and theatrical portrayal came across as more comical than menacing. But despite the fact it was hard to take him as a serious threat, he was still a compelling villain to watch. He reprised the role in Superman II and Superman IV: The Quest for Peace. (CC)1834 17. Parker Posey as Kitty Kowalski (Superman Returns)One of the few bright spots in an otherwise drab and rapidly forgotten Superman reboot, Parker Posey very much plays to type here. But it's such a delicious, mischievous performance, all eccentricity and barely-concealed madness, that it's not remotely a problem. (AW)1934 16. Joaquin Phoenix as Joker (Joker)The role that, for better and for worse, Phoenix was born to play, his Joker is disturbing and brilliantly oddball. But it’s a performance that is also suffocating by nature of how present it is. Without any respite, in the form of a Christian Bale or a Michael Keaton, it ends up feeling a lot like Phoenix swallowing you whole, and that’s not the best of experiences. (AW)2034 15. Anne Hathaway as Selina Kyle (The Dark Knight Rises)Catwoman – the thieving, on-again, off-again love interest of Batman – was brought to life brilliantly by Anne Hathaway who deftly encapsulated her slinky, feline energy and gave an emotionally nuanced performance which offered a fresh perspective on the character after Michelle Pfeiffer’s turn in the Nineties. (EH)2134 14. Lee Meriwether as Catwoman (Batman 1966)The actor, who is now 84, is unforgettable in her portrayal of Catwoman in the 1966 film. Using feline movements when she walks, she winds up with one of the best scenes in any Batman: when disguised as a Soviet reporter called Miss Kitka, complete with Sixties Beehive hair, she seduces Adam West’s Caped Crusader so she can abduct him. They have a very passionate kiss, but when he figures out she is Catwoman, he is heartbroken. (CC)2234 13. Cesar Romero as Joker (Batman 1966)It may be an unpopular opinion, but Cesar Romero always had the best Joker laugh – a shrill, gleeful racket of purely mad joy. Ruthless, menacing and dressed like the coolest cat on the Studio 54 dancefloor, he’s a blast. (AW)3234 3. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The broadcaster's flagship channel struggles&nbspamid destructive weather: 'Causing us some problems'BBC One went off-air for more than seven minutes on Sunday morning due to interference by Storm Ciara.&nbspThe BBC's flagship channel, which at the time was broadcasting Nicky Campbell's&nbspThe Big Questions, began to glitch at 11.02am before dropping off completely a minute later.&nbspThis is BBC One, I'm sorry but due to technical problems we've lost contact with The Big Questions studio in Salford, an announcer said shortly afterwards.&nbspSharing the full story, not just the headlinesInstead of moving images, the broadcast played&nbspsmooth jazz music alongside a message which read: We are sorry for the break in this programme and are trying to correct the fault.She later added: It seems that the stormy conditions up in Salford are causing us some problems. We are working as hard as we can against the weather to get back to Big Questions and Nicky in Salford as quickly&nbspas we can.At 11.08am, the announcer said the channel had solved the issue and thanked&nbspviewers for bearing with us, resulting in&nbspa failed attempt to return the broadcast to TV screens.Unfortunately we're not able to go back to Big Questions in Salford,&nbspbut please do bear with us one second, while we figure out what we're gonna do this morning, she then apologised.It was not until 11.10am that footage returned as normal.&nbspThe unusual interruption came amid travel chaos inflicted by Ciara, which is the worst storm to strike&nbspBritain in seven years.&nbspTrains, flights and ferries have been cancelled and severe weather warnings issued as&nbspCiara was forecast to pummel the UK with winds of up to 80mph.Created with Sketch. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.'It's the first time a lunar sample has been studied like this,' says researcherA new technique could provide major insights into the Moon's surface, the scientists behind it have said.The approach – which should allow researchers to find entirely new breakthroughs in pieces of lunar rock that are nearly 50 years old – involves analysing the rocks at the most minute level, in the hope of learning about the Moon.It could also help future astronauts who Nasa hopes can live on the Moon's surface in a lunar base, by allowing them to find important materials in the ground.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesWhen the last astronauts arrived on the Moon in 1972, they brought back important samples, like those who went before them. They were to be the last pieces of the lunar surface to come back to Earth, since humanity has not been back in the nearly 50 years since.That means that those remaining samples are especially precious since they are limited and can not be easily replaced. They can also be profoundly illuminating, offering us our only chance to get close to rock taken from a whole separate world.Created with Sketch.Nasa's groundbreaking decade of space exploration: In pictures Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Mystic Mountain, a pillar of gas and dust standing at three-light-years tall, bursting with jets of gas flom fledgling stars buried within, was captured by Nasa's Hubble Space Telelscope in February 2010The first ever selfie taken on an alien planet, captured by Nasa's Curiosity Rover in the early days of its mission to explore Mars in 2012Death of a star: This image from Nasa's Chandra X-ray telescope shows the supernova of Tycho, a star in our Milky Way galaxyArrokoth, the most distant object ever explored, pictured here on 1 January 2019 by a camera on Nasa's New Horizons spaceraft at a distance of 4.1 billion miles from EarthAn image of the Large Magellanic Cloud galaxy seen in infrared light by the Herschel Space Observatory in January 2012. It has since been suggested that they may instead be formed by flowing sand NasaJPLUniversity of ArizonaMorning Aurora: Nasa astronaut Scott Kelly captured this photograph of the green lights of the aurora from the International Space Station in October 2015Now researchers have found a new approach that could make the most of those limited samples as well as shedding new light on what they mean, by taking only a single piece of dust.We're&nbspanalyzing&nbsprocks from space, atom by atom, said&nbspJennika&nbspGreer, the paper's first author and a&nbspPhD&nbspstudent at the Field Museum and University of Chicago.  It's the first time a lunar sample has been studied like this. We're using a technique many geologists haven't even heard of.Scientists to make air out of lunar dust amid plans to live on MoonAs researchers make use of the new technique, they expect to find a vast set of new information about the lunar surface.We can apply this technique to samples no one has studied, Philipp Heck, a curator at the Field Museum, associate professor at the University of Chicago, and co-author of the paper, adds. You're almost guaranteed to find something new or unexpected.This technique has such high sensitivity and resolution, you find things you wouldn't find otherwise and only use up a small bit of the sample.The technique is called atom probe tomography, and involves incredibly precise manipulation of inidual grains. It has previously been used in industrial processes – but the new breakthrough has come in turning it for the first time to lunar samples.It works something like nanocarpentry, said Professor Heck: like a carpenter shapes wood, we do it at the nanoscale to minerals.The sample is placed inside a special probe and then shot with a laser that knocks off inidual atoms, which then fall onto a special plate. Researchers can examine those elements by timing how long they take to hit the detector – since heavier ones take longer – and so the type of atom can be worked out.It has already helped researchers see the weathering and materials that can be found inside the lunar soil. That in turn could help future astronauts as they move to live on the Moon, since they could survive by taking resources out of that dust.The researchers now hope they can get hold of samples from elsewhere on the Moon, and elsewhere in space, to allow them to better understand the makeup of the worlds that surround us. They compare our current understanding to analysing Earth using only one mountain range – to get a fuller grasp, they will need to examine a variety of terrains across the solar system.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Bizarre organism found in amoebae in Brazil is named after mythical sea siren&nbspViruses are some of the world’s smallest life-forms – and the jury is still out as to whether they actually are life-forms at all, as they cannot live or reproduce outside a host organism.A new form of virus is currently causing scientists to scratch their heads after it emerged the organism had almost no recognisable genes.&nbspThis “mysterious” virus collected from amoebae in an artificial lake in Brazil was considerably smaller than the viruses usually known to infect amoebae.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe team named it “Yaravirus”, after Yara, also known as “Iara”, meaning “mother of all waters” and representing a beautiful mermaid-like figure from Brazilian mythology who would lure sailors underwater to live with her forever.When the scientists sequenced the yaravirus genome – the process of determining the complete DNA sequence which makes up an organism – they discovered over 90 per cent of it was formed of the genes had never been found before.Created with Sketch.China coronavirus: Cases soar of deadly new flu-like virus Show all 113Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Volunteers in protective suits disinfect a railway station as the country is hit by an outbreak of the new coronavirus, in Changsha, Hunan province, ChinaMedical staff transfer patients to the newly completed Huoshenshan temporary field Hospital in Wuhan. title: mayor pete buttigieg democrat primary new hampshire joe biden
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Surprise frontrunner looks to consolidate&nbspIowa success by painting himself as Washington outsiderIn below freezing temperatures, the line to see Pete Buttigieg in Nashua, New Hampshire stretched out from the gym doors at Elm Street Middle School. Down the block, the line snaked around the corner, then around yet another corner.The turnout was a testament to the newfound celebrity of the candidate, a former mayor of a mid-sized city in Indiana who, just a year ago, virtually nobody in America even knew existed.But they certainly know him now. Just at the start of the 2020 primary process, Mayor Pete –&nbspas many like to call him, due to his tongue twister of a last name –&nbsphas shown that in American politics, no candidate is inevitable.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesInstead, a 38-year-old newcomer to national politics can seemingly topple the candidate folks thought was unstoppable, and head into the nation's first primary as a front-runner and candidate just about everyone is talking about. That quick rise in political fortunes does not seem lost on him.I know how seriously voters here in New Hampshire take that responsibility, that influence, that thumb on the scale that you've got, Mr Buttigieg told the crowd on Sunday. In the New Hampshire tradition that had a lot of you in the summer and the fall coming to my events and hearing me out and at the end saying, 'You know, that was pretty good. From left to right: Billionaire-philanthropist Tom Steyer, Massachusetts senator Elizabeth Warren, former vice president Joe Biden, Vermont senator Bernie Sanders, mayor of South Bend, Indiana, Pete Buttigieg and Minnesota senator Amy KlobucharMr Buttigieg heads into the Tuesday primary on the heels of a strong performance in Iowa, when voters came together last week for the bizarre spectacle that is the state's caucuses.While the reported results from that contest have been criticised for inconsistencies and muddled reporting that took days before a full account was released publicly, Mr Buttigieg's status as a front-runner out of the state alongside Vermont senator Bernie Sanders is uncontestable – even if he was criticised for seeming to claim victory far too early.The former midwestern mayor now finds himself ahead of the former vice president, Joe Biden, who once seemed like the obvious choice for moderate Democrats seeking to find a candidate with a vision that can win a Democratic nomination in a cycle marked for a surging progressive sentiment, while avoiding the kinds of policies and labels like socialist that some view as a liability for Mr Sanders should he face off against Donald Trump.&nbspI'm 98 per cent sure that I'm voting for Pete at this point, said Mary Rioux, 42, of Manchester.&nbspMs Rioux said she made her decision just after the CNN town hall late last week. Still, she said she also likes Amy Klobuchar quite a bit.Biden escalates attack on Buttigieg before tepid performance in NHMr Buttigieg still faces several notable obstacles on his path to the Democratic nomination. At 38, he&nbspis the youngest candidate in the field, a potential liability that is underscored by the fact that his highest elected office sits several rungs down from some of his most prominent opponents.On Sunday, Mr Buttigieg was introduced by Nashua's mayor and himself recognised that fact, but cast his distance from Washington as a political strength in spite of the brutal attack ads placed by Mr Biden, mockingly comparing his experience as vice-president with the kind of decisions Mayor Pete made in South Bend, like whether to put colourful lights underneath a bridge or whether to change pet chip regulations.I'm so glad to have the support of a fellow mayor at a time like this. Remember, mayors have to get things done. You're never gonna hear of a city government shutting down because two parties don't agree. We just have to make sure that the water keeps flowing through your taps so we figure it out, Mr Buttigieg said.We need to make Washington look like our best run cities and towns, instead of the other way around, he said.Why the man who sank Biden's chances in 1987 would vote for him nowStill, Jamie Bourgeouis, a 43-year-old Nashua voter, said that Mr Buttigieg seems like a sensible choice&nbspheading into 2020. She said he's not quite as progressive as she might like, but that he might do the trick.I don't know who I'm voting for yet, but I like Pete, she said. I'm torn on who to vote for. I want someone who can beat Trump. So, I'll probably go for someone who's a bit away from my personal politics.Days before the primary, Mr Buttigieg trails Mr Sanders in aggregates of polls, with 21.3 per cent support in the state compared to the Vermont senator's 26.1 per cent. Eight points below that is Elizabeth Warren, the Massachusetts senator who came in third place in Iowa and is seeking a strong showing in New Hampshire, where she has focused a considerable ground game.And so, before he can begin counting his chickens, Mr Buttigieg must prove himself in the Granite State, where voters like to tout their sense of independence, and many say they don't really care what Iowa had to say about the candidates –&nbspthey want folks like Mr Buttigieg to prove they're the right choice again.I'm just here evaluating, Carl Dubois, a 48-year-old voter from Hudson, New Hampshire, said outside of the event. He said he planned on seeing Mr Biden and Amy Klobuchar before making a final decision. I wasn't really paying attention to the Iowa caucuses. I don't really engage until New Hampshire.When will he decide? Last minute, right when I walk into the polls.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Frank Fahey helped blow the future vice-president's White House ambitions in 1987 –&nbspbut, he tells The Independent,&nbspa lot has changed since thenIn the autumn&nbspof 1987, Frank Fahey found himself in the crosshairs of Joe Biden, then a young senator from Delaware who unleashed an angry outburst at a small event early in his first run for president.&nbspAt a home in western New Hampshire, Fahey figured he would ask a question about a brewing scandal for the future vice president about his academic record, but the stress of Biden’s first presidential run –&nbspwhich was already beleaguered by claims that he had plagiarised a speech on the campaign trail –&nbspseemed to get the better of him.“We just went to a house party and Biden was there because he was a candidate for the nomination,” Fahey tells&nbspThe Independent. “And I asked him what I thought was just an innocent question and he pretty much knocked me off the wall.”Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesIt was an flare-up caught on C-Span cameras, and spread throughout the country with pre-internet virality. Responding in a way that in 2020 seems remarkably Trumpian –&nbsp“I think I probably have a much higher IQ than you do, I suspect” – Biden put one of the last nails in the coffin for his campaign, and dropped out of the race shortly after.But, some 33 years later, Fahey says&nbspthat he is ready to vote for Biden during his third race. If anything, the mere fact that Biden was on the campaign trail so long ago when someone like Pete Buttigieg was kindergarten-age underscores an experience Fahey values deeply: “I think he has had so much experience between his 36 years in the Senate and eight years as Obama’s vice president.Created with Sketch.Democratic candidates compete on the campaign trail: In pictures Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.A man holds up a sign criticising billionaires in the presidential race in front of Michael Bloomberg in Compton, Califronia. I think he knows the people to get a good team of advisers around him, so I think he could make an outstanding president.”With just two days until the New Hampshire primary, all signs point towards a disappointing third run for Biden, even as he has insisted that he could lose in both of the first two states in the primary season –&nbsphe came in fourth place in the Iowa caucuses last week –&nbspand still mount a comeback in Nevada and South Carolina.Biden escalates attack on Buttigieg before tepid performance in NHIn New Hampshire,&nbspBiden has been campaigning around the state, but doing his best to manage expectations as enthusiasm has seemed to shift away from him and towards candidates like Pete Buttigieg, Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren and Amy Klobuchar.On Friday night, early in the final debate in Manchester before voters head to the polls in the Granite State, Biden all but conceded defeat early. “I took a hit in Iowa”, he acknowledged, “and I’ll probably take it here”.It was a statement that was realistic, given the polls. title: what is coronavirus how spread symptoms
story: But what exactly is coronavirus, how does it spread and what are the symptoms Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses that can cause infections ranging from the common cold to Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome .The virus attacks the respiratory system, causing pneumonia-like lung lesions.Some of the virus types cause less serious disease, while others - like the one that caused Middle East Respiratory Syndrome- are far more severe.In  an outbreak of a similar virus, Sars, killed more than  around the world within weeks.Symptoms are similar to a common cold.They include:In most cases, you wont know whether you have a coronavirus or a dferent cold-causing virus, such as rhinovirus.Buta coronavirus infection spreads to the lower respiratory tract , it can cause pneumonia, especially in older people, people with heart disease or those with weakened immune systems.There is currently no vaccine for coronavirus.To help prevent infection, do the same things you do to avoid the common cold such as using alcohol-based anti-bacterial soaps and sprays.People should also avoid touching their eyes, nose and mouth - and avoid contact with people who are infected.A coronavirus infection should be treated the same way a cold is treated.Coronavirus is an airborne virus, spread in a similar way to colds and the flu.It is incredibly contagious and is spread through contact with anything the virus is on as well as infected breath, coughs or sneezes.This means that anyone who is infected can pass it on to any surface or person they breathe on or touch.In spite of efforts to contain the virus, it has gone international.There have been more than , cases confirmed so far.China, Japan, Thailand, Singapore, Hong Kong, South Korea, Australia, Taiwan, Malaysia, US, Germany, Vietnam, Macao, France, UAE, Canada, Italy, UK, India, Philippines, Russia, Nepal, Cambodia, Finland, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Belgium and Sweden have all reported cases.On January ,  the first two cases were reported in the UK.On February , a third Brit tested positive for coronavirus.On February , five Britons, including one child, were diagnosed with the virus in France after coming into contact with a person who had been in Singapore.The global death toll currently stands at more than , priming it to become more deadly than SARS.There are currently over , cases with nearly , of those being in a serious critical condition.In China, the majority of deaths have been in the central province of Hubei. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: praise british coast people
story: But rarely in all the debate about what our future now holds do you hear about the wonders of our coastline — which, when you think we have more than , miles of it, doesn’t feel right.Presenting Our Coast with Mehreen Baig, I’ve seen just how beautul it is, and how many brilliant people live their lives there.They are a special breed of unsung heroes.It can be tough for sure, in places the rest of us used to holiday — places we profess to love, often without actually doing that much to nurture.There are challenges in many coastal communities, and they definitely need the money politicians of all stripes have promised them.But I’ve also been struck by how hard they’re working to turn things around themselves. There is often hope where we may first see ­dficulty. You just have to look a bit harder sometimes.In Portpatrick, at Scotland’s bottom left corner, the harbour had fallen into miserable disrepair. A plan was hatched to stop the rot.A local hero organised a share issue for locals to raise the money to buy the harbour and restore the buildings around it. The village now has its pecker up again and the future looks bright.It’s a similar story on Anglesey. At Halen Mon a thriving family business draws water out of the Menai Strait, harvests the salt and sells it all over the world.Near there I met a woman called Sian Sykes who cared about those waters so much she paddle-boarded  miles around Anglesey picking out the plastic.Asthat wasn’t enough, she then paddled the whole coast of Wales doing exactly the same.But my favourite character round there is no longer with us. On the very western tip of Holy Island off Anglesey’s west coast, there is the South Stack lighthouse. It’s been saving sailors from watery deaths since .A hundred years ago, John Jones was its keeper and it was his great granddaughter Denise Shaw who took me up to the top of it.Denise showed me a photograph of her great-grandad sporting a magnicent moustache the seagulls must have coveted for their nests.He was no loner, though. Denise remembers her mum saying old great-gramps was a bit of a ladies’ man.And what a chat-up line he had at his disposal: “Do you want to come back to my place to see how bright my light is ”All four of the areas we’ve looked at for this series of Our Coast are around the Irish Sea. I had a brilliant time at Belfast docks where I joined the harbour pilots, whose work astounded me.It’s their job to bring the giant ships safely into port.I sort of assumed they did this by chugging out to meet them, lighting up a sign saying, “follow me” and gently leading them to their berths.Far from it. Round the clock, all year round, whatever the weather, they race out several miles to pull up alongside these huge vessels.Incredibly, a rope ladder is dropped over the side for the pilots to clamber aboard, make their way to the bridge, take over the controls and steer these monsters into tight spaces on the docks.The ship I boarded with them, somewhat terried, was carrying grain from Romania.As my man took the helm I asked the Polish skipper which country had the best harbour pilots. “You do,” he said, with feeling.Back across the Irish Sea, in Formby, north of Liverpool, I met Mike McComb in the £million place he’s built himself a stone’s throw from the sea.He has more bedrooms, bathrooms and children than I could count .His fortune could have bought him a lavish home anywhere in the world. But it was up here, along the endless beach, that back in the day he and his mates would come on their bikes from their tiny homes in Bootle.So, he tells me as we stand on the beach, lashed by rain and wind, you can keep St Tropez or Malibu. This coast, his coast, is where he’ll stay.The sea seems to be a magnet for the most memorable people, from Grace the crane engineer in Belfast Docks who played rugby for Ireland in three rugby world cups, to Sandy the tattooed pagan near Stranraer who says the sea’s our mother, and the Bulgarian dissident I chanced upon sitting in a hot tub ­surveying Liverpool from the deck of the Queen Mary .My grandad used to tell me that when you put your toe in the sea you’re connected with the whole world.With that in mind, I’ve enjoyed many a paddle this summer reflecting on the power and history of what our island nation is all about.And I urge you to do it, too. After all, it’s pretty easy. Britain’s most landlocked place — Coton in the Elms in Derbyshire — is just  miles from the coast. So none of us is more than a couple of hours away from the sea.There’s never been a more relevant time to get out to the edges and see the soul of this country.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: A British man infected in Singapore could be a super spreader after being linked to at least seven confirmed cases in the UK, France and Spain.A British family of four, who came into contact with the man in France, are being tested in Majorca.The number of deaths has rocketed to  with over , cases reported globally.Follow our live blog below for all the latest updates...An easyJet spokeswoman said: #EasyJet has been notied by the public health authority that a customer who had recently travelled on one of its flights has since been diagnosed with the coronavirus.#Public Health England is contacting all passengers who were seated in the vicinity of the customer on flight EZS from Geneva to London Gatwick on  January to provide guidance in line with procedures.#As the customer was not experiencing any symptoms, the risk to others on board the flight is very low.#We remain in contact with the public health authorities and are following their guidance.#The health and well-being of our passengers and crew is the airlines highest priority.#All of the crew who operated have been advised to monitor themselves for a -day period since the flight in line with Public Health England advice. title: kirk douglas was the one and only spartacus and he had balls of steel
story: When Kirk came into the world, the Battle of the Somme was still raging and Sir Ernest Shackleton — my own hero — was fighting to save his men on a doomed Antarctic expedition.At , Kirk’s death was not unexpected. But it saddened us all because it felt like this incredible human being would go on for ever.He headed the Douglas dynasty with a zest for le that put the rest of us to shame and was one of our final links to Hollywood’s golden age.Long before actors ostentatiously wore their hearts on their sleeves and made self-aggrandising speeches about the latest trendy cause, Kirk determinedly set out to do the right thing, regardless of any impact on his career.In the Fties, at the height of the Cold War, he stood up to a paranoid US government that considered anyone to the left of Genghis Khan a Soviet sympathiser.The McCarthy witchhunts ruined careers and wrecked lives, but Kirk dug in his heels and hired blacklisted writer Dalton Trumbo to work on Spartacus, which would become Kirk’s most famous movie.That took balls of steel.Kirk gave millions to charity and was a US Goodwill Ambassador, receiving the Presidential Medal of Freedom from Jimmy Carter in .He experienced heartache with the death of his son Eric from an overdose and the jailing of grandson Cameron for drug offences.But even a near-fatal helicopter crash and a stroke couldn’t defeat Kirk.His son Michael — a superstar in his own right, of course — told me last year his dad worked out almost every day with a personal trainer and remained as sharp as a tack, keeping the whole extended family on their toes.I was lucky enough to interview Kirk back in my days with TV-am.The Beeb would fly them over from LA and put them up in a posh hotel.All we could offer was a hearty breakfast, plus the chance to talk about themselves and their new project for as long as they liked.There were no pesky managers and PRs to go through.Bette Davis, Burt Lancaster, Lauren Bacall and Sammy Davis Jnr all popped into our studio at the crack of sparrows, staying for the duration of the show.Kirk was here in , promoting Dance With The Devil, a racy novel that bore a passing resemblance to his extraordinary le story.After his Jewish parents escaped persecution in Russia, Kirk was born and raised in a poor area of New York.It is a real rags-to-riches tale. His dad actually worked as a rag-and-bone man.Kirk never forgot where he came from, which is perhaps why he became a champion for justice and a fairer society.He was a delight that morning and even laughed when the crew declared, “I’m Spartacus”, one after another in his honour — though he must have seen it done hundreds of times before.He was a also a much-loved husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather.The Douglas clan will be in mourning but they can celebrate a le well lived.This weekend, I am on a Kirk Douglas marathon, starting with Paths Of Glory, before The Bad And The Beautul, Ace In The Hole, The Vikings, Lust For Le and, of course, Spartacus.Tomorrow’s Oscars will rightly honour him. We won’t see his like again.I WAS honoured to host The Millies this week.It is a wonderful event run by The Sun to salute our Armed Forces and give us all a chance to say a huge thank you.As always, there were astonishing stories of bravery, courage and self-sacrice.And as always, our lovely winners told me they were nothing special, just doing their job.I honestly don’t think they realise just how remarkable they are, or how much we owe them.One of my highlights was seeing -year-old Private Fin Doherty collect his award for inspiring others.Fin was just six when his paratrooper big brother JJ was killed in action in Afghanistan.Fin was determined to follow in JJ’s footsteps to honour his brother’s memory, and join the Parachute Regiment.He has been an outstanding addition and, in an emotional ceremony, was presented with JJ’s beret in December.Their mum Joyce admits she struggled with Fin’s decision to sign up, following the death of her eldest son.But she knew it was all Fin wanted – and she is so very proud of him.We honestly don’t deserve such an inspirational young man. But thank the Lord we have him on our side.NOTHING has changed. Phillip Schofield is exactly the same person he was before he felt the time was right to tell the world he’s gay.He’s still a loving father and husband and will still host his TV shows with consummate professionalism and skill.As Phillip said himself, you never know what people are struggling with every day and, for him, it was time to be honest with himself and everyone .I’m really glad that he has made the decision and very proud of him, although obviously it can’t have been easy.There’s been lots of tears, sleepless nights and a great deal of soul-searching. I hope he now finds peace of mind.He is a very lucky man to have a family and friends who love him very much and just want him to be happy.He also has a loyal fan base who love watching him on This Morning and that won’t change. Why would it Of course, he can expect a small number of bigots and homophobes to spew out hateful bile, but they are to be pitied and ignored.Those carping about why he took so long also need to shut up.People should be allowed to come out when it feels the right time for them.Phillip began his career at a time when being openly gay in a TV presenting role was just not an option.Thank goodness things have changed and he can be open now – and know that the overwhelmingly vast majority of us wish him and his family nothing but the very best.I was really touched by what he said about interviewing brave people on This Morning, and realising that he had to be just like them and tell his truth.Love comes in many dferent forms.Phillip and his we Stephanie adore each other and that won’t change. Again, why on earth would it At the end of his statement Phillip urged us all to be kind, especially to his family, and I hope we all take those words on board.Let’s wish them all the best and let them get on with their lives.WHAT a furore over a bare shoulder. Actress-turned-MP Tracy Brabin didn’t deserve the vitriol about her outfit but it WAS distracting.It’s unfortunate because Tracy was making important points about journalists being shut out of No  briefings – a move that makes my blood run cold and threatens Press freedom. Sadly, no one was really listening.Tracy told me she had been at a music event and didn’t expect to be back in the House. She is bemused by all the fuss.How those in public le dress should not detract from their message, be it a female MP in a low-cut top or mini-skirt, or a man wearing a gaudy tie or tight trousers.Our MPs are not known for their style and rarely make headlines for their fashion sense.I am very happy for them to keep it that way.WELL, that was a rather ill-advised memo to send, reminding local councils to fly the Union Flag on February  as a “celebration” of Prince Andrew’s birthday.I had no idea this was a “thing” and that Andrew was on a list of VIPs whose birthdays are marked with a flag waving on the roof of our town halls, instead of just cake and prosecco like the rest of us.Unsurprisingly, this ludicrous edict has caused much disgruntlement.As we know, Andrew has been booted out of The Firm by his own mum after that disastrous TV interview delving into his friendship with the American paedophile Jeffrey Epstein.Then there is the ongoing scandal over whether or not Andrew will be interviewed by the FBI as part of its investigations into child trafficking allegations against Epstein.It is all very sordid and murky. Surely even his nearest and dearest would agree this is not the time for official celebrations.He is no longer a working royal and has no place on that list.Time to lower the flags for good. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brits coronavirus wuhan milton keynes final flight
story: The passengers were transferred from RAF Brize Norton to Kents Hill Park in Milton Keynes - where theyll have access to Netflix and were handed Primark underwear.thesun … coronavirus-uk-china-liveHowever, Brit Josh Skarratts remains stranded in the Chinese city at the centre of the viruss outbreak, as he was too hot after wearing two jackets for the final rescue flight home.When officials in customs at Wuhan noted a spike in his temperature, he was barred from joining more than  evacuees flying to the UK.The plane - the second and last to be chartered by the British Government - arrived at RAF Brize Norton before passengers in face masks were bundled onto buses to Milton Keynes. On the flight were  Brit nationals and their family members along with  European nationals.  A team of  staff and medics was also on board.The group is housed in Kents Hill Park, a conference centre and hotel in a desperate attempt to stop any spread of the killer virus.The passengers were seen wearing face masks as they were ushered off the plane and onto waiting buses before finally arriving at their accommodation.They were met by medics and supplies including clothes and toiletries.Coronavirus has now claimed more lives than the  SARS outbreak as the global death toll climbed to more than  yesterday.And fears the killer virus is spreading have continued as the fourth case in the UK was recorded today.Todays flight the final plane to leave the Chinese city, which is the epicentre of the outbreak.They were today welcomed to quarantine with a letter, recognising the  days were likely to be challenging.The ambulance service said the presence of the group in Milton Keynes, Bucks, does not present a risk to local people.    A spokesman said: The local site has been chosen because it offers appropriate accommodation and other facilities for those coming back from Wuhan while they stay in Milton Keynes.It also allows their health to be regularly monitored and has the necessary medical facilities close at hand should they be required.All staff working at the facility will wear appropriate protective equipment at all times, and follow strict infection and prevention control protocols.The NHS said those at the hotel will have access to Netflix, the internet, magazines, books, baby equipment, kids toys and games, mobile phones, and tablets for reading, and games.The hotel has more than  meeting rooms and  double and twin bedrooms.Fridges and microwaves are available in every room, along with food and drinks.Brits who ed on a flight last month were taken to Arrowe Park Hospital on the Wirral.It comes after five Brits - including a nine-year-old boy - contracted the bug after it was passed to them by the third UK citizen to catch the disease.The man picked up the virus at a business conference in Singapore and then travelled to ski chalet in France where  people he came into contact with are now in hospital.Meanwhile British honeymooner was taken to hospital after he and dozens of other passengers tested positive for the virus on the Diamond Princess cruise ship, which is quarantined off Yokohama in Japan.Alan Steele, from Wolverhampton, said on Friday that he was being taken to hospital while his we, Wendy, remained on board the ship.There are  people with British passports - including crew - among the nearly , passengers and crew on the ship.Princess Cruises said an additional  people, including Mr Steele, had tested positive for the virus on the Diamond Princess, taking the total number of cases to .The company said the quarantine on the ship was due to end on February , barring unforeseen developments, and confirmed that all the affected guests were being taken to hospital.There are no plans to fly anyone off the ship and back to the UK at the moment.A separate ship in Hong Kong, the World Dream, has about  British passport holders on board. Nobody on that ship has tested positive.Meanwhile, the World Health Organizationhas shown that the reported number of new cases has fallen over the past two days, which experts welcomed with caution.There were roughly , new cases reported worldwide on February , , on February  and , on February  - the vast majority in China, WHO figures show.Patients in England with the virus will be transferred to one of four High Consequences Infectious Diseasesunits.These include two in London - the Royal Free London NHS Foundation Trust and Guys and St Thomas NHS Foundation Trust, where the third victim is understood to have been taken.There are also two in the north of the country - Royal Liverpool and Broadgreen University Hospitals NHS Trust and Newcastle upon Tyne Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust.Two other patients who tested positive for the virus last week in York are still being treated at the Royal Victoria Infirmary infectious diseases centre in Newcastle.Access to these units is restricted to a team of trained medical staff who are made to wear protective gowns, face maks, visors and gloves before they can enter.In some cases, patients will have a specially-designed tent with a ventilator set up around their bed.But experts warned it is not yet clearthis represents an actual fall in cases or whether the fall will prove sustainable.The Department of Health and Social Care said that  people in the UK have been tested for coronavirus as of pm Friday, with three cases confirmed.It is understood that the third person in the UK to be diagnosed with coronavirus caught the illness in Singapore.He is reported to be a middle-aged British man and is understood to be the first UK national to contract the disease.The man is thought to have been diagnosed in Brighton and was transferred to St Thomas Hospital in London, where there is an infectious disease unit, on Thursday afternoon.Professor Keith Willett, NHS strategic incident director, said the patient had called the NHS  service after becoming concerned.After a telephone assessment, they were advised to make their way to Royal Sussex County Hospital Brighton for testing, he said.Following a pre-arranged plan with the NHS they drove themselves to the hospital, were tested in isolation and away from public areas of the hospital, and ed home in isolation in their own car.Two other patients, who had recently travelled from China, are still being treated at the Royal Victoria Infirmary infectious diseases centre in Newcastle.One is a student at the University of York, while the other is a family member.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: andrew tip caroline dont speak out
story: And then straight away I started wondering about the more important things in le such as: What shall I have for breakfast I think that she ended up in court and I have it in my mind that she pleaded not guilty.I’m also fairly sure that she’s not allowed to speak with her boyfriend until the case comes to court. But I can’t be sure, as I have other things to think about like: I need some new trousers.Then out of the blue she announced on social media that she was going to speak out because “mine and my families le is no longer up for entertainment or gossip”.“Wow,” I thought. “That’s amazing. She doesn’t know how to use apostrophes.”It turns out, however, that while she can’t write properly, she can at least think straight because she never did speak out. Which means she stopped the story from rearing up again.If only Prince Andrew was as bright. We were all dimly aware that he knew a man in America who’d had lots of sex with young girls.And that one day, this man had been found dead in a police cell. Then we went back to wonderingwe needed more washing-up liquid.Prince Andrew, however, decided that instead of letting the story die down by not saying anything, he’d go on television to set the record straight.It was a disaster. He was suddenly front-page news all over the world and he looked guilty as hell.Of what, we weren’t sure. But whatever it was, we all worked out that as he has a Bentley, he could definitely have got from a Pizza Express restaurant in Woking to the centre of London in less than six hours.A few weeks later, as the story was withering once more, Hank J Dieselburger, an American prosecutor involved in the dead sex-man’s case, announced that the FBI had received “zero co-operation” from Prince Andrew.You’d think Andrew would have learned from his earlier mistake. You’d think he’d do a Flack and say nothing.But no. The very next day, “friends” of the Prince — which is another way of saying “the Prince” — went on the attack, telling reporters he was angry and bewildered. “They haven’t even approached me — I mean him.”The problem is that ego-fed celebrities read every single thing that is written about them. And they believe everyone  is reading everything, as well.We aren’t. We don’t really care. So when you attempt to clear your name, it’s like trying to put out a fire with petrol.It’s better for Andrew, and the whole Royal Family,he takes a leaf from singer Ronan Keating’s book — “You say it best, when you say nothing atThen, perhaps, he could take a leaf from his nephew’s book. And bugger off to Canada.I’M not defending drugs here, but when you see someone giggling their way through a packet of frozen peas and some leftover sherry trle at five in the morning, it’s easy to see why someone might think: “Yes, that cannabis malarkey looks like fun. I shall give it a go.”It’s the same story with cocaine.You see a dullard finding himself absolutely fascinating at a party and you think: “I’ll have a crack at that.”But this new drug, flakka, is dferent.One man who took it ate a homeless man’s face. Another gouged her own mother’s eyes out. And a third cut off his own penis.Which raises an interesting point. Why would anyone look at someone cutting off his old fella and think, “Ooh, I’ll have what he’s having ”A BUNCH of people who think the Lake District should only be used by ramblers decided to stage a protest over plans to put ten small tourist yachts on Grasmere lake.However, before the protest could take place, the idea was abandoned. And guess what  Yup. The protest went ahead anyway.They were actually protesting about something that wasn’t going to happen. Which proves what I’ve suspected for quite some time. Ramblers aren’t entirely right in the head.Next week, they will be protesting about the sonic booms made by Concorde and the burning of witches.LAST Sunday, driving was banned in the Italian city of Milan.Who thought that was a good idea  Getting an Italian to leave his car at home is impossible. It’s a part of his being, like his liver and his lungs.Needless to say, the scheme was not very successful.So not very successful in fact that, in the first three hours, the police had issued  fines. And the authorities now admit the ban was “largely ignored”.THERE’S much talk at the moment about how internet shopping is killing the High Street. But I’m not one of the murderers.When the time comes for my annual clothes shopping trip, I simply head to the Levi’s store on Regent Street in London, point at the label on the back of the jeans I’m wearing and ask for three more pairs just the same.I love Levi’s. I’ve worn nothing  since I was  and I’ve always loved their shop, the staff have always been brilliant. They always have what I need in stock and they never ask for my phone number or email address. I’m in and out in two minutes flat.This year, though, there was a disaster. There were two disinterested youths in there who looked at the label on the back of my jeans and said, “We don’t make those any more.”WHAT  ! !On the verge of fainting with shock, I dragged them back from their interesting conversation about Stormzy and was told in an exasperated fashion that I could still buy them online.This begs a question. What’s the point of having an expensive-to-run shopyou then fill it with people who tell you to go home and buy what you need on the net PETA, an organisation for animal enthusiasts who like to wear clothes made from crude oil, have announced that people often see their pet dog as nothing more than a cheap burglar alarm.Cheap You can buy a home alarm kit these days for less than £, whereas a proper dog is going to be way more than that.Plus, you only need feed an alarm with a tiny amount of electricity to keep it running, whereas a dog requires a bed, a blanket, food, water and, later on, vets bills that will make your eyes water.THIS week, a car crashed through my fence, turning it and an expensive new gate into matchsticks.By the time I got there, the car was gone. But there was still a lot of “police aware” tape fluttering about in the breeze.So I called the nearest station, which was approximately  miles away, as I needed to contact the driver to talk about insurance. Sadly, however, while the police are “aware” of the incident, they are not prepared to give me any details.Mustn’t grumble, though. While it will cost a few hundred quid to get everything mended, I must accept that the police have much more important things to do, such as investigating dead people who weren’t paedophiles.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
