title: bbc no longer loved broadcaster
story: If you are a lavishly overpaid BBC presenter or senior manager with your snout stuffed deep into the corporation’s publicly-funded trough, then three quid is nothing — around the price of a semi-skimmed latte made with almond milk from that delightful little café outside Broadcasting House.But coming when it did — immediately after the BBC’s wretchedly biased coverage of the moment we left the European Union — hiking the archaic telly tax felt grotesquely provocative.And I realised that the BBC’s big problem today is that it is unloved. The young folk born this century, like my -year-old daughter, do not watch it. The BBC means nothing to Generation YouTube.And the millions of us who grew up with the Beeb no longer recognise it as the benign Auntie that gave us Doctor Who, Top Of The Pops, Le On Earth, Fawlty Towers, The Likely Lads and David Dimbleby staying up all night at the General Election.That old beloved BBC — endlessly entertaining, scrupulously fair — is dead now. The BBC’s coverage of the night we left the European Union was nothing less than shameful.Here was a moment of truly historical signicance, the kind of national event that the BBC was born to cover. And it was dished up like a dull night at the Eurovision Song Contest.Down in Parliament Square, awash with Union Jacks and peaceful, happy patriots, BBC reporter Geeta Guru-Murthy blurted: “It’s a very white crowd mostly” — to the bewilderment of the many black and Asian people who were there to celebrate.But, of course, the BBC continues to peddle the filthy little lie that Brexit has its roots in the racism of the bigoted British people.Meanwhile, Sophie Raworth sat primly in a BBC studio made up to look like the EU flag. The studio never turned red, white and blue. There was no sense that the largest vote for anything in British history was being honoured. Why must we pay £billion a year for this one-sided garbage My colleague Ally Ross has pointed out that BBC “comedy” shows like Have I Got News For You, Frankie Boyle’s New World Order and The Mash Report have all been larded with anti-Brexit orthodoxy for years. Now the predictably loony Remainer-speak even seeps into the poison the BBC drips into our children.On the day we left the EU, the BBC released a CBBC Horrible Histories special mocking British stupidity.Queen Victoria was accused of callously sweetening her tea with sugar harvested by slaves — even though slavery was abolished four years before Victoria came to the throne.Historian Andrew Roberts described the mocking film as “a stream of bigoted hatred directed at this country”. They truly don’t get it in Broadcasting House. Millions of licence fee payers are deeply offended by the BBC’s relentlessly anti-British, anti-Brexit sentiment.It is why we fell out of love with the BBC. There is talk about decriminalising non-payment of the licence fee, or making payment optional. But the BBC no longer represents the entire nation. It peddles the prejudices of the disappointed elite who run it.The BBC does not speak for the British people. It doesn’t even seem to like us very much. So why should we pay anything at all for this crap AFTER being overlooked at the Oscars for her sensational performance in Hustlers, the half-time show at the Super Bowl felt like the revenge of Jenner Lopez.But Hustlers is my favourite film of the past  months. Lopez deserved an Oscar for her role.And whoever wins Best Actress at the Oscars tonight, I bet they can’t slide down a pole like her.MICHELLE OBAMA always said: “When they go low, we go high.”Meaning that when the Republican opponents of President Obama struck a low blow the Obamas had a strict policy of keeping their cool, their dignity and the moral high ground.The most senior Democratic politician in America just failed to take Michelle Obama’s advice. At his State of the Union address, President Trump petulantly refused to shake the hand of NancyPelosi, the Democratic Speaker of the House of Representatives. Pelosi should have shrugged off Trump’s rudeness and perhaps laughed in Donald’s orange face.Instead, clearly boiling with rage, Nancy ripped a copy of Trump’s speech to pieces. As the speech was full of optimistic stuff about making America a fairer, more prosperous place, the only person Pelosi humiliated was herself.The Democrats are starting to make Jeremy Corbyn’s Labour Party look like an effective opposition.THE classic James Bond films – Dr No, From Russia With Love, Goldfinger – were all less than two hours long.But in the modern fashion for over-long movies – The Irishman clocks in at three hours and  minutes – the next Bond film, No Time To Die, will be the longest ever at almost three hours.Let’s hope that means plenty of Ana de Armas, , as Bond girl Paloma. And not too much of Daniel Craig, , moaning about ’s dodgy knees.Teenage girls are messier than teenage boys. But teenage boys are, in my experience, more likely to leave takeaway pizza under the bed for six months for the mice to nibble.And when vermin move in, you really long for your little darling to move out.SUCKING up to the millionaire snowflakes in the audience, Prince William complained about the lack of ersity at the Baftas.I don’t believe it. This year a black actor, Micheal Ward, won the Rising Star Bafta for gang film Blue Story. Six years ago,  Years A Slave won Best Picture, competing with epic Hollywood fare like Gravity.If the film or performance is good enough, then the Baftas is colour blind.The real lack of ersity is among British actors. These days most of them went to Eton with Prince William. Now that’s what I call a lack of ersity.A SURVEY reveals that  per cent of Canadians are against paying the £million to-£million-a-year security bill for Harry and Meghan’s new le.Wherever they lay their hats, from Toronto to Tinsel Town, there is only one sucker who will ever pay for Harry and Meghan’s security. The poor old British taxpayer.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: queen calls meghan markle prince harry back
story: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex moved to Canada after announcing they were quitting as royals and becoming financially independent.But the -year-old monarch has reportedly asked them toto the UK next month for the service at Westminster Abbey.If the couple attend the March  event, it will be the first royal engagement for Meghan, , since they quit.And the Sunday Times reported the couple will make a round of final official engagements in March before ing back to North America.The couple attended the Commonwealth Service last year, with Meghan heavily pregnant with Archie.Theto the UK comes after Harry and Meghan released their bombshell statement that they were leaving the Royal Family - even paying back the £.m spent refurbishing Frogmore Cottage.And they have since settled into le at a £.million Canadian mansion on Vancouver Island, rubbing shoulders with A-listers including Jenner Lopez with speculation they were even invited to the Oscars.Most recently, Harry made his first public appearance at JPMorgan’s Miami billionaire’s summit, where the sixth-in-line to the throne gave a speech - rumoured to have been paid million plus expenses for the gig.But the Sunday Times reported the Queen was remarkably unfazed by the couples new le.She has told friends: “If that’s what they want,they want to go, we must let them go.”The couple were reportedly flown on the JPMorgan private jet from Vancouver to Palm Beach, where they’re said to have stayed at the home of Meghan’s longtime friend, tennis legend Serena Williams.The summit was attended by the likes of Patriots owner Bob Kraft and billionaire philanthropist Robert Frederick Smith.It comes after it was reported Meghan is looking for an agent in a possibleto showbiz.It was claimed she is actively looking for representation after she and Harry declared they wanted to become financially independent as they quit the Royal Family.A source told Us Weekly the -year-old is actively looking for a manager or agent for future projects.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dad uk since 11 and has baby with brit mum to be deported to jamaica
story: Reshawn Davis, , who has a baby with his British we, was detained last Friday and told he would be removed to Jamaica on Tuesday.He said he was terried about ing to Jamaica and feared he would be targeted.The -year-old is being booted out the UK because of a robbery conviction from  years ago. Mr Davis spent two months in jail.He was convicted under the joint enterprise law that was used to convict people in gang-related casesdefendants could have foreseen violent acts by their associates.In  the Supreme Court ruled the law had been wrongly interpreted for  years.Mr Davis, who lives with his Brit we and six-month-old daughter in northwest London, has not committed any crime since his conviction.He is set to be deported with around  other Jamaican nationals on Tuesday.Boris Johnson said it was right to send back foreign national offenders.Speaking from Colnbrook removal centre following the decision, Mr Davis, who has no family or friends in Jamaica, told The Independent: Im so stressed out. I cant even explain how I feel.Yes I was born in Jamaica, but I was brought up here. I dont know anything . I made one mistake in le, and it feels like I tried to kill the Queen.I look at my daughters pictures now every night before I go to bed. Since she was born I never had never spent a night without her until I was locked in here.I still reach for her when I wake up. Im not one of those to leave my we to do it by herself. I want to be there for them both.Im terried to go to Jamaica. My cousin was deported and he has now died. People will be hostile to me because Ive been deported. Im going to be targeted.His we of five years, Tonique Kerr, , said her husbands deportation would prevent her from going back to work and force her to have to claim welfare benefits.Ms Kerr, who is currently on maternity leave but works as a complaints handler at an energy company, told the newspaper: I had been hoping to go back to work so he could look after the baby. I wont be able to. Thats not something I wanted because I dont want to sit down and rely on benefits. Ive always worked. Ive never been on benefits in my le.I never imagined being a single mum. I dont want to fall into the statistics of young single parents, especially for something that isn’t my fault and could have been prevented. Its hard, emotionally and I would need help financially because it is hard having a young baby.Reshawn is a great dad. Hes been here all the time with her. She loved him. He does a lot – feeds her, changes her, plays with her. A child needs their dad. I don’t know what’s going to happen now.Mr Davis MP, Dawn Butler, said she objected to him being branded a serious criminal.The shadow women and equalities minister said: His we feels like this stress is going to kill her husband because he has a heart problem.She backed calls for the flight to Kingston to be halted until we establish the true facts of the situation.Mr Davis lawyer argued that he should be allowed to remain in the UK because of his family ties.However it was ruled on Friday that he did not have a genuine and subsisting relationship with his we or daughter and that it would not be unduly harsh for them to be without him.In a Parliamentary briefing last week, the Joint Council for Welfare of Immigrants said it was concerned some of the passengers could be potential victims of trafficking or victims of county lines exploitation.The issue was raised at Prime Ministers Questions, when Labour MP Nadia Whittome called for the flight to be halted until a review into the lessons learnt from the Windrush scandal was published and its recommendations implemented.The Windrush scandal saw many of those who had arrived in Caribbean countries between  and  detained or deported despite having the right to live in the UK for decades. The fallout led to the resignation of Amber Rudd as home secretary.A Home Office spokesperson said: The planned charter flight to Jamaica is specically for removing foreign criminals. Those detained for removal include people convicted of manslaughter, rape, violent crime and dealing class A drugs.The spokesperson added that everyone on the flight will have had their cases fully reviewed to ensure there are no outstanding legal barriers, including trafficking and slavery claims, that would prevent their removal from the UK.The law on joint enterprise was challenged in  following the case of Ameen Jogee, who had been convicted of joint enterprise murder of former Leicestershire police officer, Paul Fyffe in .While the court heard that it had been Jogees friend, Mohammed Hirsi, who stabbed Mr Fyfe in the heart, he had egged him on and both were convicted of murder and given le sentences.But during the appeal, Jogee argued he was not inside the house when the incident took place, and could not have foreseen what his friend intended to do.Delivering the judgement, Supreme Court judge Lord Neuberger said it was wrong to treat foresight as a sufficient test to convict someone of murder.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brit holidaymakers magaluf good behaviour contract
story: Tourists could also be fined £, for jumping off balconies in new measures designed to stamp out drunken tourism in party resorts.Hotels who fail in a new legal obligation to kick out guests engaging in the dangerous practice, known locally as balconing, have also been told to expect the same type of fines.A document drafted by the Majorca hotel federation FEHM has been sent to its member hotels in Magaluf and the nearby S’Arenal resort.It states: “The hotel management informs clients that it is forbidden to engage in practices which endanger le, health and physical integrity in this establishment, for example by passing from a balcony or window to another and jumping from unsuitable locations into the swimming pool.“Guests who carry out these dangerous practices will be expelled immediately by hotel management, with the assistance of the forces of law and ordernecessary.”Holidaymakers where hotels decide to implement the change will be asked to sign and date the document and record their passport and room numbers at check-in.The code of conduct also highlights the fines that can be levied on guests who break the rules and warns them: “We also inform you that taking drinks of any kind outside the hotel is strictly prohibited.”Maria Jose Aguilo, vice-president of the FEHM which has  member hotels in Majorca, said the association was recommending the introduction of the document but confirmed it was “optional.”She told  local paper Ultima Hora: “The only objective here is to offer more legal protection in case of claims.”Officials at the association said was too early to say what the take-up by hotels would be.The new decree against drunken tourism was announced on January  and took effect following its publication in an Official State Gazette five days later.It was approved by regional MPs on Tuesday. Only far-right wing party Vox voted against ratying the decree, branding it “discriminatory” and “botched” and predicting it would lead to job losses.The decree covers Magaluf, S’Arenal and the West End part of San Antonio in Ibiza which is also popular with British holidaymakers.It bans pub crawls and drink offers like happy hours in those areas.The decree, valid for five years, also limits the number of alcoholic drinks served in restaurants and hotels as part of all-inclusive offers to three at lunch and three at dinner.Party boat operators are banned from picking up and dropping off revellers in the areas the law covers. And shops in the resorts will be banned from selling alcohol between .pm and am.A regional government spokesman confirmed after its introduction: “The new rules establish a penalty regime which puts special emphasis on serious and very serious misdemeanours.“Those practices which are dangerous and cause risk to le or endanger the integrity and health of clients or the tourists who engage in them, will be considered serious misdemeanours. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus businessman super spreader
story: The middle-aged super-spreader contracted the deadly virus while at a conference in Singapore and is then believed to have passed it on while staying at a chalet in France.A frantic search is underway to find the hundreds of people he may have had contact with.The businessman flew back to Britain on an easyJet flight from Geneva that landed at Gatwick on January .It throws open the possibility he could have spread the virus to the  passengers and six crew.The mystery super-spreader was unaware he contracted the virus during a conference at the Grand Hyatt hotel in Singapore organised by British gas firm Servomex.He then flew to France where he inadvertently spread the deadly virus after staying four nights at a ski chalet in Contamines-Montjoie owned by Brit Bob Saynor, who is now infected along with his nine-year-old son.Five Brits who shared the ski resort were diagnosed over the weekend and hundreds of people at the resort have been tested.More than  people have died and , have become infected since the outbreak began in Wuhan, China.The family is understood to have been living in the village for just three months after moving from Hove, West Sussex.A Brit dad was also quarantined in a Majorca hospital after testing positive and Spanish authorities appeared to confirm the case was again linked to the French ski chalet.Mr Saynors we Catriona had left France by the time the investigation began and is under observation in a UK hospital.It is not clearshe was the fourth case diagnosed in Britain.French officials have closed the -pupil primary school attended by the Saynors nine-year-old son and a -pupil school in nearby Saint-Gervais he attended for one day last week will also be shut.Etienne Jacquet, the mayor of Les Contamines-Montjoie, said the chalet had now been disinfected.It was confirmed tonight that he flew back to Britain on an easyJet flight from Geneva - an hour from the chalet - that landed at Gatwick on January . He fell ill shortly after landing and was rushed to a hospital in central London.In a statement easyJet said:easyJet has been notied by the public health authority that a customer who had recently travelled on one of its flights has since been diagnosed with the Coronavirus.Public Health England is contacting all customers on the flight which was flight EZS from Geneva to London Gatwick on  January, to provide guidance in line with procedures.As the customer was not experiencing any symptoms, the risk to others on board the flight is very low.We remain in contact with the public health authorities and are following their guidance. The health and wellbeing of our passengers and crew is the airline’s highest priority.All of the crew who operated have been advised to monitor themselves for a  day period since the flight in line with Public Health England advice.Note this happened  days ago and none are displaying any symptoms.”Medical experts say the incubation period is up to  days with those coming from the centre of the virus in the Chinese city of Wuhan usually showing symptom after seven days.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: storm ciara shocking moment child blown road
story: The family had gone out for a walk amid the Storm Ciara carnage, despite severe weather warnings from the Met Office yesterday.As the strong gales whipped through the country the youngster was filmed being shoved off the pavement by a gust.They and their family appeared to be running as they tried to escape the wet and windy weather.And as one of the parents lost control of a buggy they were jogging along with the little one tumbled into the road.Chasing after a sibling the youngster skidding on a puddle and fell to the floor before being buffeted into the street.Onlookers screamed as the youngster slipped and fell as a parent rushed to help - also fighting the wind.He had been out in Blackpool, Lancs yesterday at .pm with one other child.Another woman pushing a buggy was walking alongside them.One witness said: “It was a really daft thing to do. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA row has erupted between Boris Johnsonaposs partner Carrie Symonds and his chief advisor Dominic Cummings over the Cabinet reshuffle, it has been claimed. Miss Symonds is apparently backing ministers who claim Mr Cummingaposs heavy-handed treatment of ministers, officials and journalists is harming the Prime Ministeraposs image, according to Treasury sources.Reports that the advisor urged the PM to sack Chancellor Sajid Javid and Defence Secretary Ben Wallace - two ministers with close links to Miss Symonds - has stoked the flames of the feud. Mr Johnson is said to be against firing Mr Javid but how secure Mr Wallace remains is unclear with a reshuffle likely to happen this week, reports the Daily Mail.Mr Cummings is also understood to be looking to remove several Tory ministerial special advisers, some who are close to Miss Symonds. The Prime Minister could be dragged into the centre of a potentially damaging power struggle between the pair - the most powerful members of his Cabinet of key advisors. Miss Symonds and Mr Cummings each have prominent Cabinet allies and hobby horses fighting their corners. The former joined the party as a press officer a decade ago before being pushed up to director of communities three years ago, working for senior Conservatives John Whittingdale, Zac Goldsmith and Mr Javid.  She is described as a skilled networker, as well as being a environmental campaigner, with her animal welfare views and stance on the release of violent criminals having influenced Mr Johnson.Mr Cummings, meanwhile, pioneered radical school reforms as special adviser to then-Education Secretary Michael Gove and is hailed as the genius behind the Vote Leave campaign in aposs EU referendum. During a party on January , marking Brexit night, the Prime Minister praised his chief advisor for coming up with the powerful aposGet Brexit Doneapos slogan, paving the way for his landslide General Election victory in December. Mr Cummingsapos war on the mainstream media since then though has seen him come under fire, including recently banning reporters from organisations considered hostile to the Government, resulting in a revolt of Westminster lobby journalists. He had also banned ministersapos special advisors lunching with journalists, to avoid stories being leaked, though both he and Miss Symonds have close ties with certain senior journalists. It is also understood he is behind a Number  campaign to chop the BBC down to size, including blocking ministers from appearing on Radio aposs Today show, claiming it is anti-Tory. A Treasury source told the Mail: There was always a risk that Carrie and Dom were going to fall out and that the PM would get caught in the crossfire.

story: NewsTheresa May made deliberate decision to stop Boris Johnson being in charge of BrexitEx-Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt has admitted it was a “deliberate decision” to take Brexit out of the Foreign Office when Boris Johnson was foreign secretaryShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsFormer British Prime Minister Theresa May felt that Boris Johnson, the public face of Vote Leave, had been determined to undermine her attempts to get Britain out of the European Union" to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTheresa May made a “deliberate decision” to stop Boris Johnson taking charge of Brexit when he was Foreign Secretary, it is being claimed.  His successor at the Foreign Office, Jeremy Hunt, suggested that Downing Street had not trusted the leading Brexiteer to deliver on her plan.  Mr Johnson later spectacularly quit the Cabinet claiming that the UK was headed “for the status of a colony”Mrs May’s soft Brexit plans were adopted. But many at No  felt that Mr Johnson, the public face of Vote Leave, had been determined to undermine her attempts to get Britain out of the European Union ever since she took over at No .  In an explosive interview with the Institute for Government, Mr Hunt said: “It was a deliberate decision to take Brexit out of the hands of the Foreign Office while Boris was Foreign Secretary, that was what No.  intended.”  The ex-Cabinet Minister claimed that when he took over Mr Johnson’s job in  the department became “a bit more involved”. Mrs May created the Brexit department in July , in the wake of the referendum vote, and handed it the responsibility for the UK’s departure from the EU instead.   But in the same series of interviews, her de facto deputy David Lidington claimed it had been “a mistake” to do so and Brexit should have been run from the centre of Government instead.  He added: “There should have been a dferent approach to the [Brexit] negotiations at the start, because I think it would have been possible then to come to the deal earlier.”  And he disputed claims by ex-minister Liam Fox that the civil service had dragged their feet over Brexit - claiming they were “working flat out” and would have “done their utmost” to deliver the politicians’ wishes. Mr Lidington also claimed that he had backed Mr Johnson’s Brexit deal - which was % Mrs May’s - after the PM privately assured him that a no deal departure was “not something that any sensible PM would choose”.

story: NewsDad-of-five who lived off Pot Noodles while on the dole now runs £million businessGary Fredson, from Runcorn, Cheshire, says he was left nearly destitute after losing his home, car and other possessions following the collapse of his businessesShareCommentsByTom Houghton:,  FEB NewsGary Fredsons properties and car were repossessed and he was struggling to feed his family " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA dad-of-five who lived off Pot Noodles after nearly going bankrupt now heads a multi-million pound business. Gary Fredson has experienced both dizzying highs and scarring lows in his career. He achieved remarkable success as one of the countryaposs top retail managers before losing it all, with his properties and car repossessed.But he got back on his feet and eventually launched a profitable solar energy firm ESE Energy, reports the Liverpool Echo.The business recently represented Liverpool at a top utility conference in Paris following a year of success and expansion. Having grown up on a council estate in Runcorn, Cheshire, Gary left secondary school to go straight into employment, working as shop assistant at Currys. He soon progressed to a full-time salesman at the computer brand and within four years, became one of its top sales people. That brought him into the multimillion pound club for sales - success that propelled him to the role of store manager at the age of . Dad-of-five Gary said: It was very young to be a store manager. “The average age for one at that point was late s or early s. I was managing people a lot older than me. I was managing people who had previously been my manager, but I was very passionate about sales and giving a good customer service experience.” Gary was then headhunted to run a branch of office supplies shop Office King in Liverpool in  - becoming the youngest manager to work for the company. That was before moving to electrical retail store Powerhouse in Speke Retail Park in , where he became area manager, responsible for £m worth of turnover. But this was the point where things began to take a turn for Gary, starting with Powerhouse going into administration in , making half of their staff redundant. In , the firm entered receivership. Gary said following the earth shattering news he was to lose his job, he began some consultancy work in helping startup businesses. He said: “The money I received from my redundancy I also invested in property. Buy to let was a great market to be in. But the financial crash in  brought further bad news for Gary.  He said: “Interest rates were high. People couldnapost get mortgages, and many were losing their jobs. “A lot of people had several properties but their tenants were not paying rent. I had no money myself and was actively looking for work. “But with my background, there wasn’t much out there. I was a retail professional who worked in customer service and I had a bit of HR experience. “There were lots of people from banks who had lost their jobs too, so they had saturated the market. That meant I was unemployed for a while.” Personal financial problems for Gary grew, and soon enough, on the verge of bankruptcy, his house, along with all of the properties he owned were repossessed, and his car taken off his drive. He said: “ came and I was living in a flat, on the dole and getting housing benefit, on a prepaid gas and electricity meter. “I was broken at this point. I didn’t have WiFi in my house, I didn’t have a laptop, I couldn’t even afford to use my car. “I was missing direct debits for insurance, and struggling to eat. I was on Pot Noodles. There was no McDonald’s or eating out for me. Put simply, I was single and on the verge of destitution. Describing it as a “dark time”, Gary likened the situation to how some professional athletes can struggle after retirement. He said: “People say footballers have to try and adjust after they stop playing, but I think thataposs the case with anyone whoaposs been very successful and then all of a sudden has lost. “It was bleak so I hated everyone - I was very negative. You find you have lots of friends when you are very successful, and when youaposre not, you donapost tend to.”  Gary said he felt like he’d lost “a little bit of dignity”. He added: “I couldnapost hold my head up high - having to ask my dad to lend me some money to buy my daughter a present for her birthday - itaposs a bit crap. I went four years without going on holiday.” Determined Gary began to take measures to change his mindset and focus on his personal wellbeing in a bid to turn the situation around. He said: I wanted to be a bit more positive. I wanted to think about setting myself goals on a daily basis.” By chance, he developed an interest in eco technology after speaking to an engineer who had been called out to his rented accommodation due to a problem with the boiler. He found out about a government initiative called the Green Deal - giving tenants the chance to pay for energy efficient home improvements through savings on their energy bills, and began to research eco energy and eco funding. Before long, he had been enrolled onto a course in Warrington, training to be an energy surveyor, and soon after qualying, found a job working on commission with a £ basic salary. He said: “It was all about walking the streets, knocking on doors and getting sales. That’s what we did.”  He launched the firm in  and by  had moved into solar energy. An initial success was delivering a solar energy contract for Nottingham City Council, installing the technology on , properties. A sht in the market then saw the firmaposs focus sht away from installations to providing service and maintenance to firms using solar energy, with a key focus on helping people out of fuel poverty. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHarry Dunn’s outraged family are demanding a public inquiry after the fugitive accused of killing the -year-old in a road smash was revealed to be a CIA agent. Mum Charlotte Charles said the news that suspect Anne Sacoolas had a more senior role with the agency than her spy husband made her feel “downright lied to” by the British Government. Ministers and officials were said to be aware of Sacoolas’s career in espionage. But she was not declared as an agent when she came here with intelligence officer husband Jonathan. And Mrs Charles, , said the revelation means “things are now beginning to fall into place” on why the US is blocking her extradition to face justice. Slamming the Government, she said: “How could they do this to us  We have thrown ourselves into building relationships with the Government, despite the terrible way they were treating us. I am livid and my family are full of anger. How could they keep this from us  “This doesn’t affect the fact that Anne Sacoolas is coming back, which she is. “But to hear how they have not been candid with us takes us back to those terrible days when they were trying to kick this all under the carpet. I do not know what the Government think they are doing or why they are treating us the way they are. It is an absolute scandal.” Family spokesman Radd Seiger added: “At a recent meeting with the Foreign Secretary, the parents asked him specically what Anne Sacoolas’s role was.“He confirmed what we all knew – she had in the past been an employee of the State Department. But he made no mention of the fact that she was CIA. Something has clearly gone badly wrong and it is no wonder Boris Johnson has not seen it fit to meet the parents and I. “I now call for a full public inquiry into who knew what and when, and into the deplorable manner in which this family have been treated.” Sacoolas’s Volvo allegedly hit Harry’s motorbike last August while she was driving on the wrong side of the road. The -year-old fled the country after the smash outside US base RAF Croughton in Northamptonshire. The US claims it notied the Foreign Office that she was leaving. In December, Sacoolas was charged over the fatal accident and she has apologised for Harry’s death. But she refuses toand US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has rejected an extradition request.

Deit Deitreich-Briggs, , looks after his grandchildren five or six days a week from am to pm, plus a couple of nights, to enable his daughters to work. The Birmingham pensioner loves to cook for Lacey, eight, Indie, six, and Zayn, six, and also collects them from school, helps them with homework and supports them during their out of school activities. Running to a tight budget on his pension, Mr Deitreich-Briggs says he manages to feed the four of them for just £ a week.Among the dishes he prepares for the children, there are homemade fish and chips, pizza and mini toad in the holes, Birmingham Live reports.At the weekend, the kids often like to help their grandad bake chocolate and vanilla cakes for them to eat during the week. “I love having a close bond with my grandchildren and wouldn’t want it any other way,” the retired retail manager said. I enjoy making all our food from scratch, ensuring itaposs healthy and balanced, and teaching the children to cook too. Mr Deitreich-Briggs, from Erdington, Birmingham, is a widower so he cares for his grandchildren on his own.  We have an extremely good breakfast every day and then they go off to school laughing and happy, said Deit, they are doing well and are happy, they’ve got that stability. They also do their homework every morning before going to school. He gives them tea at pm then takes them to football, swimming and the gym before their parents come to collect them. The -year-old, who is a yoga teacher, then goes to work. Among his tips to cook healthy meals on a budget, Deit said it is important to plan and prepare ahead, make sure nothing is wasted. Other tips include storing leftovers, shopping at value supermarkets, using honey instead of sugar and getting the kids a meal chart. We totally trust him to make the right decisions. When the kids are in his care, it’s his rules and what he wants to teach them. His daughter Zita Deitreich-Irving, , works as a part time legal secretary so her son Indie goes to his grandadaposs three days a week.  On the days when she is not at work, Zita meets her dad, niece and nephew to do the school run together and she helps Deit take them swimming on a Monday too. story: NewsI went looking for my real dad and found the brother I never knew I hadRoyal Navy veteran Peter Stantons lelong search for his father ended with him discovering half-brother, Larry Arnold, , who lives in FloridaShareCommentsByLouie Smith:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB News " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA Royal Navy veteran who has been searching for his dad since he was a teenager has discovered he has a brother. Peter Stanton, , was raised by mum Hilda after she got pregnant following an affair with a US sailor. He began searching for his father Roland aged  and had almost given up hope. But he uploaded his DNA online and was put in touch with half-brother Larry Arnold, , who lives in Florida. Dad-of-four Peter said: “We actually look alike, it is absolutely amazing. I was over the moon. “He used to play golf and I used to play as well and there are loads of silly similar things like that. “I was really disappointed that I missed my father. He passed away in  aged  but to know I have a brother feels out of this world. “I just want to give him a hug.” The pair are now making up for lost time by chatting on Skype weekly and plan to meet in person. Larry added: “I am completely in awe of this whole thing and I am looking forward to the day we meet. “I have so many things I want to tell him about our father. “I would have loved for dad to have known Peter. He would have been so proud.” Roland joined the US Navy aged  and served as a minesweeper. He was stationed in Plymouth, Devon, when he met Hilda during preparations for the Normandy invasion.  But following the Second World War he ed to the US, leaving her pregnant and heartbroken. Peter joined the Royal Navy Gunnery Division aged  to follow in his mother’s footsteps, and served for  years. He sent DNA to ancestry five years ago but there was no match until Larry, who was in the US Army National Guard, registered himself. Larry told him Roland believed Hilda had given birth to a daughter. Peter, of Walthamstow, East London, explained: “He had a wire signal back when he ed to the States and he tried looking for the girl and could never find her and he couldn’t locate my mother either. “Obviously the signal was wrong.  “He also seems to think my mother looked pretty much like his mother, which could be the reason they got together.” Sadly the half-brothers discovered they have both suffered from types of cancer.

story: NewsMcDonalds worker lists secrets that took him from £-an-hour to £million a yearDean Chapman, , dropped out of school before completing his A Levels but now runs a food business of four branches with a turnover of £millionShareCommentsBySanjeeta Bains:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsDean Chapman, , started his business career at McDonalds " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA McDonaldaposs employee who became the man behind four of the UKaposs biggest and busiest franchises has given his top business secrets. Dean Chapman, , snubbed university to serve burgers at McDonaldaposs and now runs a business boasting four branches with a turnover of more than £ million. The dad-of-three, from Leicester, took his first McDonaldaposs job aged  job to generate cash for a college canoeing holiday. But now, Dean and his team run restaurants at Cherry Street near Temple Row, Bristol Road, near Belgrave Middleway Stephenson Place, on the New Street ramp, and Kings Parade in Dale End, Birmingham Live reports. Deanaposs blue collar parents -  dad was painter and decorator and mum a machinist - were less than thrilled when he decided to ditch his A Levels to work full-time at the Golden Arches.  But he worked his way up from McDonaldaposs crew member to director level. In  he was appointed Head of Franchising UK, helping franchise owners run and manage their restaurant more effectively. In , he resigned as a McDonaldaposs employee to buy his own restaurants as a franchisee. Dean said: I first bought two - Stephenson Place and Dale End. A year later I took on Cherry Street, followed by Bristol Road. All the McDonaldaposs in Birmingham are franchisee owned. Dean said: When I started only around  to  per cent of UK McDonaldaposs restaurants were franchises - that is owned by independent business owners like me. It was not the UK model then. Now around  per cent of McDonalds restaurants in the UK are franchises. It has grown hugely. With a turnover of more than £.million, according to public accounts published for the year ending December , , he is certainly doing something right. Dean put his success down to hard work, graft and a bit of luck along the way. He said: If you put your heart and soul into the work, the opportunities are there. So what are his multi-million pound secrets   What were you doing before you started at McDonaldaposs  I was studying Physics,  Maths and Electronics at Leicester College. I wanted to be an electrical engineer and planned to go to university - I would have been the first in my family to go. I got a part-time job at my local McDonaldaposs in Leicester to help pay for a canoeing holiday.  When I came back from the holiday, I continued to work at McDonaldaposs and I ended up working more and more hours. I was practically a full-time employee before I knew it. I guess my lightbulb moment came after I ed from my holiday. I remember sitting in class at college, putting my hand up to ask to be excused to go to the toilet and being told I couldnapost and that I should have gone on a break. I threw my toys out of the pram, walked out and never went back. My parents were very disappointed,  I wasnapost going to university. Obviously they donapost feel that way now.  What I loved about the job - which is still true today - was it was all about teamwork and camaraderie. I’m a very shy person in general but after a few weeks I found my feet and within a few months,  I was running the kitchen with  staff. How do you progress from crew member   The management set-up back then was quite dferent. By the age of ,  I was running my own restaurant. I became Leicester area manager at . While going through the ranks I got a lot of training and business qualications at what we call hamburger university - an office in Sutton Coldfield. These are courses not externally recognised but when I go into organisations to talk about the franchisees, the stuff I’ve been taught are well-known business models.  My last few jobs as a McDonaldaposs employee were as director of operations and head of franchising in the UK. Why did you decide you wanted to be a franchisee  The higher up I got in the company, the further away I got from what I loved - interacting with staff. When I was training franchisees for the company, Iaposd give advice about what they could do to run a better McDonaldaposs and move the business forward. I wanted to implement these things myself. Now I have my own franchise business consultant  - the job I used to do -  who gives me a fresh pair of eyes and a good overview. Have your children any plans to follow your career path  They are very proud and it is a family business - my we is the bookkeeper. I have three children, Heidi, Finlay and Luke. Finlay has a natural affinity with business and wants to study that at university.  Luke and Heidi love maths. She is studying maths at St Andrews, where Kate Middleton and Prince William met. Apparently an Indian princess is studying there now! How do you become a franchisee and how much money do you need  You need an initial outlay of unencumbered cash of £,. And be accepted for an application programme. The selection process is quite intense. There is an extensive application process. Then there is a nine-month training period after that. Whataposs the best thing about being a franchisee  Seeing people progress. All my managers worked from crew up. I think it would be frustrating to work somewhere where there were no ways to progress - absolutely the opportunities are there in McDonaldapossyou want them.  For example one employee Cha who was on our apprenticeship programme started as crew in October  and was promoted to sht manager within four years. aposYou need an initial outlay of unencumbered cash of £, to own a franchiseapos You have to work very hard and put your heart and soul into it. There are other employees who donapost want to go up the ranks - which is fine. They just want a flexible job - and some cash to let them focus on other interests, whether that be sport or the arts. What changes have you seen since you started  When I started we didn’t sell breakfast - shocking when you consider how popular it is.   On the back of customer demand we have increased the breakfast time from .am to am so people can have a lie-in.  I remember the film Falling Down, when Michael Douglas is told he is a few minutes too late for the breakfast menu at a fast food restaurant and explodes. We donapost want people to feel like that! Also back when we started, it was just filter coffee. The only chicken we sold was nuggets. Now  per cent of our products are chicken.We sell as much chicken as beef. As the years have progressed,  peopleaposs tastes have evolved. More recently we have offered salads, veggie wraps and vegan dippers. Who knows what it will look like in  years  The restaurants themselves have transformed massively over the last five years, we have table service, the My McDonald’s app and McDelivery. Describe your average day Every morning I get up at  and drive to Birmingham. Iaposm usually at the Dale End branch by .am. Iaposll get the business managers for the four stores together for a couple of hours.  Then they go back to their teams and have similar meetings with their teams. The rest of the day is spent catching up on emails. Every day starts with a meeting of some description - so it could be a team meeting. It could be a franchisee meeting, so we get together as franchisees and the community as well I currently have seven business managers working for me. I give them targets - feedback on how they are performing.

story: NewsopinionNada Farhoud: Electric transition could drive us all to distractionAs Prime Minister Boris Johnson announces a ban on the sale of new fossil fuel powered vehicles from , what car should we buy - and will the subsidy remain ShareCommentsByNada FarhoudEnvironment editor:,  FEB NewsopinionElectric cars are the future - but hybrids, it seems, are not" to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWe were urged to buy hybrid cars believing they were environmentally friendly. But now tens of thousands of motorists, who were encouraged by the ­Government, have been given a kick in the teeth. It turns out they were not quite as efficient at lowering emissions as was originally thought. Boris Johnson this week brought forward a ban on the sale of new petrol and diesel cars from  to  to ­coincide with the launch of a UN climate summit in Glasgow later this year. He said Britain, as the first country to industrialise, had a “responsibility” to lead the way in cutting emissions. A welcome move.  But the decision to extend the ban to all hybrid cars is confusing and enraging. A vehicle is one of the most expensive purchases we will make. Many owners now also fear the fiasco will see resale values e as the ban approaches. Who wants to buy a car that will be illegal in the near future  Tests have found that the new ­generation of plug-in hybrid cars emit up to three times more greenhouse gases in “real world” driving than official figures suggest. The reason for this is that hybrids – which contain an extra electric motor and battery – tend to be heavier than their petrol counterparts. In addition, many plug-in hybrid owners are neglecting to charge their vehicles, running them on petrol alone and losing the benefits of the dual system. We have been greenwashed before. The move is ­comparable to the knee-jerk Labour policy of diesel tax breaks, which led to increased air pollution and was later discredited.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailStorm Ciara smashed into Britain with winds close to mph causing biblical flooding and travel mayhem nationwide. Nearly , homes were left without power after a month’s worth of rain fell in one day in some areas. Dozens of flights were cancelled with others erted as far away as Germany because of the perilous conditions from the high winds and torrential rain. One BA plane was forced to declare an emergency and land in Lyon, France as it ran low on fuel while waiting to touch down at Gatwick. As waves up to ft high battered the coast, hundreds of PO ferry passengers were stranded at sea for hours as the Pride of Hull struggled to dock. Have you been affected by Storm Ciara  Email webnews@mirrorThe Isle of Wight was cut off after ferries were stopped as winds of mph were recorded at landmark The Needles while the port of Dover was also closed. Sporting events, including Manchester City’s Premier League clash with West Ham were called off. Helen Roberts, from the Met Office, said: “In terms of area this is probably the biggest storm this century.” She added she had not seen amber warnings – the second most severe level – “on this scale across all of Wales and much of England”.  “This could end up being the biggest since ,” Ms Roberts said, when the “Great Storm” killed  people and felled an estimated  million trees. Her colleague, Alex Burkill, said that this was just the start warning of “plummeting” temperatures this week. There would be dangerous ice in the North he said, and snow showers affecting many parts of the country.  “Once we say goodbye to Storm Ciara, it’s not a complete calm-down by any means,” Mr Burkill said. “It’s not a pleasant outlook. It’s going to stay very windy, we’re going to have plenty of heavy showers with hail and thunder and some snow.” Yesterday’s winds damaged multiple buildings including London’s Victoria station and a guest house in Hawick, Scotland, which partially collapsed. Trains were cancelled and planes in Manchester and London aborted landings faced with mph winds.  Residents had to be evacuated in Lancashire and Yorkshire as rivers burst their banks and a major incident was declared by Lancashire police. Families hit by Boxing Day floods in  were in the line of fire again and those hit by November’s River Don floods were warned to “be prepared”. Sirens in the West Yorkshire town of Hebden Bridge warned of what was to come. Hours later, parts of nearby Mytholmroyd were under ft of water as it flooded for a third time in eight years.  Resident Adele Smith said: “Utter devastation in my home town of Mytholmroyd and Hebden Bridge and a catastrophic failure of the flood alleviation scheme, which is nowhere near finished. “For all those non-believers of global warming visit the Calder Valley.” Keith Crabtree, a flood warden for nearby Todmorden added: “I can sum it up in one word: grim. “That’s through the whole of the Valley, ...there’s problems all the way down. “It’s striking me like another Boxing Day... the number of incidents are certainly at Boxing Day  levels.”  Yorkshire shepherdess Amanda Owen watched a metal livestock carrier being swept away on a hillside. She said: “The energy and power of this storm are unreal. The gusts of wind are exceptional and water is pouring. “Can’t believe this just happened. A flood of biblical proportions.” Emergency services ferried residents to safety using inflatable boats in the Lancashire towns of Bury and Ramsbottom. And Bury councillor Tamoor Tariq helped families board a bus to a temporary rescue point set up at a local leisure centre.  Mr Tariq told the Mirror: “It’s so deep we’ve had to close off the roads, we had to support people coming out the properties because some of the water was knee high. There are bins floating around and lots of residents outside their properties.” The Environment Agency issued  flood warnings and a red “danger to le” was declared for severe flooding from the River Nidd at Pateley Bridge in North Yorkshire. Three people were injured when a pub roof in Perth, Scotland, collapsed.

title: voice mirror hs2 rail link
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: HS rail link is the route to a more prosperous futureGiving the HS rail link the green light is positive, but the Tories must take responsibility for dithering which added to spiralling costs after Labour launched it back in ShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  FEB NewsopinionArtists impression of the Curzon Street HS station in Birmingham" to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailGiving HS the green light will end grumbles that France and Japan, to name only two countries, build high-speed rail links quickly while here in Britain we’re stuck on the slow track. However, the Tories must take responsibility for dithering which added to spiralling costs after Labour launched HS in . Even now Boris Johnson repeats past mistakes by leaving a question mark over routes north of Birmingham instead of giving a vote of confidence in the whole line. Making savings wherever possible to keep down the final bill is most important - but the huge HS project is vital. It will boost rail capacity and speed up journeys. HS will also help spread wealth by linking England’s North and Midlands with more prosperous London and the South East. The benefits might not be felt until it’s running, yet no Government committed to rebuilding Britain could derail HS and pretend to be constructing the future.  Storm warning Storm Ciara’s ferocious battering will be felt long after the winds have died down and floods receded. Homeowners, businesses and travellers will be left facing the cruel storm’s aftermath. Bad weather is expected at this time of year, yet there is no doubt that the ever more extreme swings of Mother Nature are being triggered by the climate emergency. Just as Australians accept the devastating bush fires were inflamed by a changing climate we may come to recognise it is behind increasing floods and storms in Britain. If we don’t look after Earth better our planet will turn on us – and we’ll deserve it.

title: hundreds people ski resort tested
story: NewsHundreds of people at ski resort tested for Coronavirus after Brit child, , diagnosedDozens of people who came into contact with a British child suffering from coronavirus have been tested for the disease in the ski resort of Contamines-Montjoie, in FranceShareCommentsByAlexandra WilliamsMatthew Dresch:,  FEB NewsThe test results are expected this evening " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHundreds of people who came into contact with the British child infected with Coronavirus in the French Alps have been tested for the deadly virus. Worried families, wearing facemasks, gathered at a medical centre adjoining the childaposs school in Les Contamines awaiting the results, which are due this evening. Officials have closed the -pupil primary school for lessons this week in the small ski resort, an hour from Geneva. The nine-year-old son of British couple Bob and Catriona Saynor, who moved to the Alps three years ago, is in hospital in France after being airlted from the resort on Friday afternoon. The local ambulance service estimated  people had been tested by Sunday afternoon. Health Minister Agnès Buzyn, speaking at a hastily arranged press conference in Les Contamines, said: “We have prioritised the children who have been in the most contact with the affected child, then the children who have symptoms and finally those who are less at risk because their contact has been reduced. “The situation is changing, our decision will depend on whether we have positive results in the evening.” Environmental consultant Mr Saynor, , has also been diagnosed with the deadly virus along with three other Britons from another family who were staying in the Saynor’s six-bedroom ski chalet. Mr Saynor’s two other children and four other Britons from the other family are in isolation in French hospitals as a precaution. A second school in nearby Saint-Gervais, which has  pupils and was attended by the Saynor’s son for one day last week, will also be shut this week. The mayor, Jean-Marc Peillex, advised against panic. He said: “We must not panic an entire population. We want to put into perspective the risk of contamination - the young Briton did not rub shoulders with a whole school but he rubbed shoulders with five students for half a day.” The Les Contamines Ski Club, where the child is a member, cancelled training on Sunday. One mother, whose child is friends with the British boy, was taking him to be tested. She said: “It’s scary. My son has had five days of high fever. Is it ‘flu  Is it something   We don’t know. I think it’s more contagious than they want to say.” Didier Mollard, a father of a child at the Les Contamines school, said: “We are taking their temperature twice a day and are watching them closely. We are worried  per cent for sure. “ Émilie Bétourné, a mother whose son attends the school, said: “My son is in the class of the brother of the child who is infected. “I am not panicking for the moment. I am waiting instruction from the doctors. We’ll listen to what they say and observe the health of our children. School is closed for the week.” Les Contamines village was eerily quiet on Sunday. The resort should usually be bustling with the start of the Paris half-term.  Local Sophie Lanier said: “It shouldn’t be this quiet in the resort. I think a lot of businesses are going to be worried that people won’t risk coming. It’s sad.” Skiers buying lt passes early Sunday morning also expressed their concerns. Joseph Dubois, , who was skiing with his we, said: “It’s a small ski station and we are a bit worried. We don’t know where the family went and who is now infected. It is a concern for certain.” Another skier, Laurent Guy, from Paris, said: “I have been coming here for a long time to this resort and I feel sorryit is going to be hit hard financially. It is a worry, of course, but we’re staying.” Annick Roger, director of the tourist board, said: Weaposve had a lot of calls.

title: a breather for united is just what the doctor ordered at tannadice
story: Saturday’s defeat for Dundee United showed the players need a bit of a breather – luckily for them they’ve got one this weekend.United fans would probably want a match to go to on Saturday but a rest weekend is just what the doctor ordered for Robbie Neilson and his men.What they’ve done this season already is a massive achievement and the day was always coming closer that they’d be punished for an off-day.That happened against Arbroath at Tannadice .There had been warning signs from the Red Lichties on their previous matches there – a - draw in the Challenge Cup and then leading - going into stoppage time before losing - in the league.Their gameplan obviously was effective and they stuck with it to good effect this time around.The dference on Saturday was United didn’t have enough about them to get a result.For me, that’s most likely a sign of fatigue, and possibly a wee bit of complacency.It’s really dficult to avoid the latter, particularly when suffering from tiredness.There’s also the build up of injuries.Nicky Clark is out for the rest of the season. His replacement Osman Sow was stretchered off on Saturday. Unfortunately, it sounds like he’ll sit out the rest of the campaign as well.But it’s a sign of the quality they have in their squad that Clark and Sow can be missing and you still have a striker of the calibre of Lawrence Shankland to lead the line. vw, px"  Sow being out leaves a great chance for youngsters like Declan Glass and Chris Mochrie to show what they can do in the No  position.It’s unfortanute for people to get injured but also a great chance for some of United’s youngsters to impress.On top of Sow’s injury, Paul McMullan, Louis Appere and Calum Butcher have been carrying injuries recently, too.This week is an ideal time to give the players a bit of a break and recharge the batteries for the run-in.The Tangerines want to get that title wrapped up as soon as possible but this breather couldn’t have been better timed.Once again, other teams weren’t really able to make up any ground on the runaway leaders – Inverness clawed one point back at home to Alloa.United are the only team that have managed any sort of consistency this season – a wee break is just what they need to get going again.

title: boxing fanatic gary todd describes brushes with the biggest stars in the sport since move from st marys to sydney

title: current dundee crop must find their voices says former hero rae
story: A squad packed with huge characters roared Dundee to their last Championship title.Now the skipper of that side has challenged the Dark Blues’ beleaguered current crop to find their voices.Gavin Rae capped a glittering -year playing career by leading Dundee to the Premiership six years ago.It was a team full of influential figures.And Rae wants the top boys in today’s side – two of whom he knows well – to instil some pride ahead of a crucial play-off run-in.“I came up against Christophe Berra on a number of occasions,” said Rae.“He was always a tough opponent – and he’s got loads of experience to draw on.“Graham Dorrans, I roomed with him on Scotland duty. It was very late in my international career and very early in his to be fair!“But you just have to look at his career to see the quality he’s got. You don’t play in the Premier League for as many years as he did without being a very, very good footballer.“These are the guys that can turn it round for Dundee – the big characters.“The season I captained the team to the Championship title, we had loads of characters in that dressing-room, and it kept us going through what was a rollercoaster season.“It was touch and go at times but guys like Peter McDonald, Ian Davidson, myself, Kyle Benedictus and Christian Nade kept it ticking over.“You need leaders in any successful team, and with Christophe and Graham in the current side, they should be the ones setting the standards.”Standards of late have not been high enough at Dens Park.A run of four Championship games without a win since the festive season has seen the Dens men drop out of the play-off places.For a side who started the season with designs on a title charge, that is a cause for concern.But Rae believes the talent peppering the Dee squad ought to be enough to turn the tide – and ensure at least a shot at a quickfireto the Premiership.“If you look at the Dundee side, there are guys with plenty of Premiership experience there,” he said.“You’ve got Jack Hamilton at the back, Christophe in front of him, Dorrans in the middle, Kane Hemmings up top . . . the list goes on.“These are the guys James McPake will be asking to drive the team on in the second half of the season. vw, px"  “They’ve been there and done it – some of them at a very high level.“So you have to think thatthey turn it on, they’ve got enough about them to get Dundee firing again.“Things have been tough in recent weeks and being out of the play-off places is not good.“The players have to fight to turn that round because another season in the Championship isn’t ideal – and it could easily happen.“But, for me, there should be enough experience and quality there to turn the tide.”

title: elliott happy to be utility man if it means upturn in dee fortunes
story: New boy Christie Elliott says he’s happy to arrive as Dundee’s utility man – as long as it means the Dark Blues can get their act together in their promotion play-off push.The former Partick Thistle player takes on his old side this weekend in what’s likely to be his home debut.After last weekend’s - draw at Morton , where Elliott came off the bench in the second half, Dundee’s recent record doesn’t make pretty reading with no wins in their last five games in all competitions.They are still searching for a first victory of  as they dropped down to sixth at the weekend.For a new signing coming in, though, Elliott has the chance to make a real dference to the side’s fortunes – in whatever position the manager chooses.Elliott told the Tele: “To be fair, I’ve played a lot of positions in my career!“I’ve played mostly on the wing but, as formations change, I’ve played wing-back and at right-back.“Anywhere, left-wing, left-back, right-back, I’m happy to do a job for the team.”He added: “It was good to get my debut, get a few minutes on the pitch and, hopefully, I can help create things for the team and get the team going on a good run.“It is a massive club and when the opportunity came along I was really happy to take it.“The club deserves to be in the Premiership and,we can get a few wins in the league, we’ll be back up in the play-off mix.“It’s in our hands sowe can get a good run going we can still get where we belong, back in the Premiership.”Elliott was signed by Jackie McNamara for Partick Thistle back in  and stayed at Firhill until last summer when he headed back to his native England to play for Steven Pressley at Carlisle.Pressley’s time at Brunton Park ended in November and Elliott found action hard to come by. vw, px"  He said: “It was hard at Carlisle, a new manager came in and changed things. That happens in football.“I want to play and I’ve played the majority of my career in Scotland so when the opportunity came up to join a massive club, there was only one thing on my mind and that was to come up here and get it sorted.“I came up to Dundee last Friday and was in the stadium the majority of the day getting things sorted.“I knew a few of the boys from before but Saturday was the first day I actually met the team so it’ll be good to have a full week together before this weekend’s game.“It is hard to come into a team like that, you just have to adapt quickly.“It can actually be a good thingyou don’t know many people because you have to make an effort to get to know them and their game.”And Elliott has been impressed with the quality in the Dens Park squad, evenhe felt they should have done better in his debut at Cappielow last Saturday.“There are big players in this team. It comes down to the better team on the day, though.“We can have a lot of big iniduals butwe gel as a team we’ll get going. The main thing in this league is consistency.PODCAST: Twa Teams, One Street – United need a breather and Dundee’s new No  impresses" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp podcast-twa-teams-one-street-united-need-a-breather-and-dundees-new-no--impresses embed # secretsakulqcN" data-secret"sakulqcN" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"“Saturday felt like a defeat, to be honest, because we should have done a lot better.“They were down to  men for the last half-hour and we didn’t create enough chances.“We probably put too many balls into the box when we didn’t have enough bodies in there. I think we should have kept the ball a bit more and looked for the opening rather than putting in long balls.“Morton put every player behind the ball and, in games like that, I think you have to keep the ball, tire them out and wait for the opportunity.”

title: field aiming for new lease of life after dens move
story: Dundee’s latest signing Tom Field says he has come to Dens Park to “re-invent” himself as he gears up for his debut.The Dark Blues take on Partick Thistle tomorrow and -year-old left-back Field is desperate to get out on the Dens turf after a frustrating time at Brentford where his last first-team outing was almost a year ago.He told the Tele: “I had been at Brentford for seven-and-a-half years so it was tough to leave but the time had come.“I played a fair few games in the Championship and in cup games but there were good players there, some they’d paid a lot of money for.“It’s hard to get in front of players sometimes coming from the academy.“I had a go, it didn’t work out so now I’m here to re-invent myself. I need games, it’s one thing training week in, week out but without playing you miss out on so many things.“In a game, everything is dferent, you want to win, there’s three points on the line. I haven’t played for a while so I’d love to play  minutes tomorrow.”Field’s move north was a late one, only being confirmed less than an hour before the transfer deadline last Friday.But he says he jumped at the chance when he heard Dundee were interested.“It was about three, four o’clock when I heard about it,” he added.“I had to rush back to the training ground, sort everything there and I didn’t have to think about it – I was going to Dundee as soon as I heard.“There were other clubs but Dundee were the right one for me.“I didn’t have any worries coming up here.“There were a few Scottish lads in the Brentford B team who I’ve talked to – Ali Coote, who is from here, Jonny Mitchell, Theo Archibald.“Ali had left for Waterford before this move came around but we’ve messaged each other and he said ‘definitely go’.“I don’t know much about Scottish football, to be honest, but I do know that out of all the teams in the Championship, Dundee try to play.“That’s a big reason why I came here.”As well as a recommendation from former United man Coote to move to the city Field will have another reminder of home tomorrow.Reece Cole, on loan at Partick Thistle from Brentford, is a good friend and Field hasn’t been slow in ramping up the banter ahead of tomorrow’s game.“I know Reece really well,” Field said.“I joined Brentford a week after he did so we are really good mates. I’ve told him I’m going to leave one on him! That’s a joke, obviously.Alex Jones is there, too, and I know him from Bradford so there’s already been a lot of banter.”The young full-back is also familiar with Dens Park.“I’ve been here before, I watched a game.“Lee Carsley was our U s manager and we came for a pre-season tour, playing a few teams and we watched a game against Everton here at Dens Park.“That was five years ago so I don’t remember much but I do remember the atmosphere being good. It was pre-season but there was still a great atmosphere.” vw, px"  Field’s deal with the Dark Blues is only until the summer but the left-back is happy just to be given a chance to get football.“That suits me,” he added. I need game time.“Some people might say ‘he’s only got six months’ but I see it as having six months to prove myself and that gives me an edge because I have to hit the ground running.”

title: michelin pledges 5m investment in dundee area with at least 850 jobs expected to be created
story: Michelin is relaunching a scheme which the company says will help create hundreds of jobs in Dundee and Angus, worth around £ million.Michelin Development will provide funding and advice to firms with the potential to expand – providing high-quality, long-term employment, bosses have said.The firm said #at least  jobs are expected to be created# and Michelin Development has also #targeted support for  new jobs#.Funding from Michelin Development could be used to attract companies involved in the green transport industry to the new Michelin Scotland Innovation Parc .MSIP is a joint venture between Dundee City Council, Michelin, and Scottish Enterprise.It aims to drive growth and ersity in the Scottish economy while addressing the global climate emergency.Bosses aim to deliver #a world class innovation centre, driving global research  while influencing and supporting breakthroughs in sustainable mobility and low carbon energy#.The news comes as politicians and business leaders from across the region will attend an event today to learn more about the £m programme.Successful applicants could receive unsecured, heavily-subsidised loans and free, independent and expert advice to pave the way for growth, Michelin Development said.It was announced in November  that the firm would close the plant, with the loss of all  jobs.The tyre factory is due to cease production by the middle of   after the French firm deemed it #unsuitable# in the current climate.Michelin Development said it will target inward investment by providing grants for companies looking to set up in Dundee.Bosses are urging businesses with high potential, and medium-sized enterprises in and around Dundee, Arbroath, Carnoustie and Forfar – or businesses considering investing in these areas – to get in touch.Mike Cole, head of Michelin Development in the UK, said: “Manufacturing, engineering or business to business service companies with fewer than  employees are eligible.“If you have a solid business plan and the potential to create high-quality jobs, but you just need that bit of extra help, then we want to hear from you.“Michelin Development is here to support employment in and around Dundee by helping high-potential firms and entrepreneurs turn their ambitions into reality.”Loans of up to £, are available, and they can be used to lever additional funding from other sources.The event will take place at the MSIP – and funding from Michelin Development could be used to attract companies involved in the green transport industry to the new facility.At least  jobs are expected to be created at MSIP, and Michelin Development has also targeted support for  new jobs.John Reid, Michelin Dundee factory manager and the chief executive of MSIP, said: “This is a signicant announcement for MSIP, for the Michelin Group and for the Dundee area as a whole.“When we announced in  that the Michelin Dundee factory was to close in , we pledged to support our employees and deliver a legacy that will benefit the regional economy for generations to come.“We are determined to create at least  jobs on the Michelin Scotland Innovation Parc and Michelin Development is another string to our bow. It will help attract investment and employment to both MSIP and Dundee.”Dundee City Council leader John Alexander said: #It#s a real source of strength that Michelin#s commitment to the city extends beyond the Michelin Scotland Innovation Parc.#This fund has already helped more than  businesses with loans of more than £ million.#I#m delighted that the Michelin Development Fund is set to continue with that support.#Businesses in Dundee will benefit directly and we will continue to work across Dundee to grow jobs and investment.#Michelin Development is backed by a steering committee made up of organisations including Michelin, Angus Council, Business Gateway, Dundee and Angus Chamber of Commerce, Dundee City Council, Scottish Enterprise and the Royal Bank of Scotland.For more information on Michelin Development, visit michelindevelopment.

title: residents claim lack of footpath at childrens playpark in dundee could lead to an accident
story: A brand new children#s playpark which has been built without any footpathis an accident waiting to happen, according to concerned locals.The children#s play area, which has been built next to the new Our Lady#s primary school along Alexander Street, is home to play equipment such as climbing frames and a chute for the primary school children to enjoy.But despite it being a recent development, there is no concrete footpath allowing for people to access it # meaning residents are forced to cross a #mud bath# to enter.Moira Cameron, who was volunteering to help clear up litter than had been left along the street, spoke of the problems that teachers and parents could face when the kids are playing there.She said: #There should definitely be a path that leads straight to the equipment, this is a brand new park but the grass is in such a mess.#It#s a mud bath. I would hate to think that when the kids are on their morning or lunch break and are playing here, they could fall and let#s face it, that would be a nightmare to clean.# vw, px"  The recent weather has left the grass in such a state that Ms Cameron is concerned it could lead to kids falling and getting hurt.The Hilltown resident added: #The children tend just to run in without thinking they could fall.  It can be a bit slippy underfoot so you need to watch.#It#s a shame it looks like this when we are putting in effort to keep the area clean.#Hundreds of youngsters start school at Dundee#s newest campus" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp hundreds-of-youngsters-start-school-at-dundees-newest-campus embed # secretyHHycJqvB" data-secret"yHHycJqvB" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"It#s not just the adults who are concerned about the dangers posed by the unkempt grass, with local teenagers also speaking of their concerns.Stephanie Whyte, , said: #It#s really hard to get into the park with all the mud.#They should really put in a path,someone were to slip and they were next to the gate they could possibly break a bone.#Eilidh Russell,  added: #We were here before the new school got built and as far as we were aware, there was never any plan to put a path in.#It#s definitely not ideal.#A council spokesman said: #We are looking into the matter.#
