title: oscars-2020-really-matter
story: ITrsquoS Oscars Night. The world will stop this evening to watch a carnival of wealth, adulation, fame, talent, glamour and ndash most of all ndash power. It is a night bestowed with global signicance. Millions around the planet see it as the cultural and artistic heart of the year. Wersquore told that the Oscars matter.But is that true  Do the Oscars say anything about the world we live in, about our culture, our society  Or is it all, as the cynics believe, just an empty, gaudy show that signies nothing Who decides First of all, letrsquos be clear what the Oscars are. Like their British equivalent, the Baftas, the Oscars are an expression of how a very narrow sliver of society sees both culture and the world at a specic moment in time. When it comes to the Oscars, that sliver of society is the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.It is the academyrsquos roughly , members who hand out the gongs. All members are part of the film industry ndash directors, cinematographers, producers ndash but actors make up the biggest proportion, %.Of the academyrsquos active voters, % are white, % male and % over , and about one-third are former Oscar nominees and winners. Given wersquore in Hollywood, the academy also has a liberal bias. Right-wing movies ndash unless yoursquore Clint Eastwood ndash donrsquot get far.For such a youthful art form as cinema, the old, white, wealthy, male demographic is jarring ndash and it lies at the heart of the Oscarsrsquo ersity problem, with not enough black or female artists up for awards.The question of raceThe movie Green Book, which won Oscars in  for Best Picture, Best Original Screenplay and Best Supporting Actor for Mahershala Ali, is a good case study when it comes to liberalism and ersity.In an elevator pitch it sounds the perfect pro-ersity film: a white, working-class man learns to be a better person by working for an intellectual black man.The only problem is the film was hammered for its ldquowhite saviour narrative. In the film, the black guy only learns about himself thanks tothe white guy. Green Book was criticised for perpetuating a fantasy that racism only happened in thepast ndash itrsquos set in the s ndash ratherthan today.Green Book is a perfect example of Hollywood trying to be liberal, but falling on its face with a story about black le filtered through white eyes. If the academy wanted to hand the Best Picture Oscar to a ldquogood film about race last year it could have awarded BlacKkKlansman by Spike Lee.American powerSo the Oscars represent a very narrow worldview. They also represent a very American worldview. Of course, America is the planetrsquos cultural powerhouse, but the Oscars crowd out the vast majority of films which donrsquot come from the English-speaking world.The rules have a built-in bias against foreign films. Any contender for the big awards ndash Best Picture, Actor, Actress, Director, Screenplay ndash must play for seven nights in LA. That might be hard for a brilliant but broke filmmaker from Africa or Asia.The nominee for Best Foreign Film doesnrsquot have to open in America ndash but it does have to be its countryrsquos official selection, which in itself is a mountainous task of networking, campaigning and schmoozing.The schmoozeSpeaking of schmoozing ndash thatrsquos the other problem which erodes belief in the Oscars having real cultural signicance. If you want your film to win you need deep pockets.Winning an Oscar is all about campaigning ndash and campaigning costs. In , Doctor Dolittle was a turkey. Over budget, critically hated and a box office disaster, it still managed to get a Best Picture nomination, and eventually won Best Song and Visual Effects after th Century Fox launched a champagne-fuelled charm offensive for Academy members.In , the schmaltzy Shakespeare In Love beat Saving Private Ryan when Harvey Weinsteinrsquos studio Miramax spent an unheard-of  million on an Oscar campaign.Money, however, does not buy cultural signicance, or lasting appeal. Who cares about Shakespeare InLove today The golden ageSo the Oscars have more than their fair share of problems ndash and itrsquos hardto argue that the awards, as a whole, have something consistently signicant to say about the world, cultureand society.However, that doesnrsquot mean inidual Oscar-winning films arenrsquot important. Many speak directly about societyrsquos big issues, the problems confronting the world and the changing shape of culture. When the Academy gets it right ndash which isnrsquot often ndash it gets it very right.The seventies is a good era to explore ndash after all, itrsquos the golden age of modern cinema. In , Kramer vs Kramer swept the boards, winning five Oscars including Best Picture. It stars Dustin Hoffman and Meryl Streep, and tells the story of their orce. The film focuses a lot on their child, Billy, caught in the middle.Billy was a symbol of generation X ndash the first generation to grow up with orce normalised. The film explores gender roles ndash who should raise a kid and why  ndash womenrsquos rights, fathersrsquo rights, the growing demands of corporate careerism, work-le balance and single parenthood. Kramer vs Kramer was socially astute and culturally ahead of its time.That same year Apocalypse Now won two technical Oscars ndash Cinematography and Sound. Today, itrsquos Francis Ford Coppolarsquos film which has stood the test of time much more than Kramer vs Kramer.Divorce is no longer a zeitgeist subject, but Apocalypse Now continues to say something culturally signicant: that Western power is dangerous. Often it is films which are nominated for Oscars, but donrsquot scoop the Best Picture award, which make the most interesting cultural statements. In , the academy basically replicated what happened the year before ndash it gave four big gongs to another family drama, Ordinary People.However, Raging Bull ndash hailed as one of the greatest movies ever made, and a film which has easily outlasted its Oscar rivals ndash only won two awards, including Best Actor for Robert De Niro as the boxer Jake LaMotta. It was a study in ldquotoxic masculinity decades before the term was coined.Sometimes, though, the academy just goes a bit mad ndash like in  when it gave four Oscars to Network but still handed the Best Picture award to Sylvester Stallonersquos Rocky. Network is a brutal, brilliant satire, which still says something culturally signicant about the media and society.War: where it all beganIf we go right back to the first Oscars, in , we see the Best Picture winner, the war film Wings, struggling to make sense of the First World War. The US Library of Congress has listed Wings, which starred early screen idol Clara Bow, as a film of ldquocultural signicance because it was a real pioneer in the industry.The following year, , saw cinema still wrestling with the aftermath of war and looming danger in Europe. All Quiet On The Western Front was the big winner. After protests by the Nazi Party in Germany, the film proved its cultural signicance by promptly getting banned.The Second World War profoundly affected the Oscars as neutral America tilted towards Britain. Gone With The Wind ndash although racially unsettling today ndash made clear that war was monstrous. It beat The Wizard Of Oz to the Best Picture award in . Oz, though, summed up better the sense of dislocation, confusion, fear and nostalgia sweeping a world facing global conflict.In , British and American culture fused when Mrs Miniver ndash which tells the story of an ordinary English housewe during wartime ndash took six Oscars, including Best Picture, Director and Actress . Casablanca won Best Picture the following year with a clear message about Americarsquos attachment to Europe: wersquoll always have Paris.The big issuesAs the years march on, we see that so many Oscar nominees were commercially successful but artistic non-entities. The Curious Case Of Benjamin Button, anyone Still, a few of the Best Picture winners stand out, capturing perfectly the spirit of the times in which they were made. On The Waterfront, which won Best Picture in , looks at le from a uniquely th-century working-class perspective. West Side Story in  used the cover of a musical to tackle immigration.In , though, To Kill A Mockingbird ndash a film fuelled by the US civil rights movement ndash lost out to Lawrence Of Arabia. David Leanrsquos epic is a visual delight, but itrsquos a clunking and colonial take on the Arab world.In The Heat Of The Night, the  drama starring Sidney Poitier as a black detective in the Deep South,won Best Picture and put African-Americans front and centre. In , homosexuality was explored in Midnight Cowboy, although the film is critiqued for homophobia today.Mental illness was the theme in when Best Picture went to One Flew Over The Cuckoorsquos Nest. Gandhi in  turned attention to colonialism. Rain Man in  looked at autism ndash albeit in an exceptionally misinformed way. And American Beauty in  grappled with the crisis in masculinity.IdentityFrom the turn of the millennium, it is often who the filmmaker is rather than the film theyrsquove created which makes the biggest cultural statement. The Hurt Locker took six Oscars in  and made history when Kathryn Bigelow became the first woman to win Best Director. An emotionally astute war film, it signalled the power dynamic between the sexes shting both in Hollywood and across the west.Then, in , Moonlight took Best Picture. Itrsquos a film about being black, gay and poor, by a black writer-director, Barry Jenkins, and with an all-black cast. Itrsquos one of those films which crystallised the time in which it was made ndash in Moonlightrsquos case right in the middle of Black Lives Matter.In , the bizarre fairy tale The Shape Of Water won Best Picture. Beneath the surface lay an examination of female sexuality, with all its quirks and wonders laid bare. Its central character, played by Sally Hawkins, may be mute but the story is about women finding their voice in the world of men.This yearrsquos nomineesSo what of tonightrsquos Best Picture nominees  Do they speak to our times  Certainly some do. Joker is perhapsthe film with most cultural clout.Some see it as a comment aboutthe left-behind, gun nuts, socially awkward losers and the alt-right.Thatrsquos mistaken, but evenit weretrue it would show a film unafraid of tackling the big social questions.What Joker really explores is the increasing isolation of modern le, the breakdown of community, the corruption of decency in an amoral world. In the era of social media, hate, and disinformation, Joker couldnrsquot be more of its time. It speaks directly to the experience wersquore all going through right now.However, itrsquos unlikely Joker will win Best Picture ndash though Joaquin Phoenix should be a cert for Best Actor. Joker is too edgy for the academy to give it the top prize.The most likely winner is . Wartime heroism wins awards ndash think Schindlerrsquos List and The Pianist. The only thing that wins more awards than wartime bravery is Meryl Streep ndash nominated a record  times.Sam Mendesrsquo First World War film does speak of something prevalent in our society ndash nostalgia for a glorious past. The veneration of the past lurks within the rise of Western populism. Thatrsquos not to say  isnrsquot a good film, it is ndash itrsquos just that it says something a little disturbing about our current cultural obsessions.The gangster epic The Irishman sees Martin Scorsesenot just to form but also old ground as he rummages through the undergrowth of toxic masculinity again. Jojo Rabbit, a dark fairy tale about le in the Hitler Youth, may seem quirkybut itrsquos also back on safe Oscar territory: wartime heroism.Like Greta Gerwigrsquos multi-nominated Lady Bird in , Little Womencontinuesthe rebalancing of the cultural scalesby telling stories specically about women and by women. The Netflix movie Marriage Story is essentially a Kramer vs Kramer reboot for millennials.Ford v Ferrari finds itself in the slot marked ldquowell-made film that no-one particularly cares about. Still, it had enough star power to ensure nominations. In terms of cultural import, itrsquos al. Think The Big Short from  ndash nominated for five awards, won one. In a decade, few will remember it.Quentin Tarantinorsquos Once Upon A Time In Hollywood is fun, but itrsquos really just an in-joke for Tinsel Town. For comparison, therersquos Robert Altmanrsquos  movie The Player ndash it too was Hollywood on Hollywood and earned a clutch of nominations. Again, few remember or care today.Parasite is the oddball in the mix. Firstly itrsquos foreign ndash and although foreign films rarely make it into the Best Picture category, the last few years saw things change with The Artist, which inexplicably won in , and Roma, which inexplicably lost to Green Book last year.Could a South Korean comedy-horror win Best Picture  If wersquore judging a film on what it says about culture and society then Parasite should be a leading contender. If you want a movie which explores lersquos inequalities and the deadly nature of the rich-poor ide, then pick Parasite.Who emerges as top dog all depends on whether this is a year when the academy gets it right, and rewards a film which explains where we are right now when it comes to culture and society ndash orthe academy gets it wrong and just slaps a gold star on what it thinks is an important film, but is in reality just an ephemeral piece of entertaining fluff which says nothing about the world.

title: scotlands-gardens-scheme-peek-secret-spaces
story: In a tiny corner of what was once Glasgowrsquos shipbuilding heartland, bordered by a steel spiked fence and overlooked by a car park, a garden oasis waits to wake from its slumber.Lovingly created on a derelict site of a former shipyard, the delphiniums, ornamental grasses and gerbera of the Duchess of Montrose Memorial Garden have brightened its small corner of Govan since it openedlast summer.Normally restricted to a select few visitors, the city garden is tiny compared with the manicured grandeur of Gardyne Castle,  miles north in Angus, with its perfectly pruned knot garden, bluebell wood, fishpond and immaculate lawn.Meanwhile, at the rear of a fairly ordinary semi-detached house in an ordinary street in Ayrshire, therersquos an extraordinary garden growing ndash exotic tree ferns, towering bamboo and feathery palms have turned what wasa bog-standard Scottish back garden with typically crumbling shed and untameable ivy into a minitropical jungle.For gardeners who have not been blessed with a single green finger, these and dozens of other lovingly nurtured and weather-defying gardens are either something to aim for or a reason to just throw in the trowel.They are among hundreds of gardens up and down the country now being pruned and planted in preparation for Scotlandrsquos Gardens Scheme, an annual showcase which celebrates the often hidden beauty of the nationrsquos private havens, community allotments and therapeutic school and retirement home gardens.Many of the  gardens taking part are labours of love, growing in defiance of wild Scottish weather and carefully cultivated by gardeners more likely to be found dusting the rose bushes than relaxing on a recliner wondering why the freesias have died.Around % of gardens involved in this yearrsquos scheme feature specially created wildle areas designed to attract birds, bees, butterflies and bugs ndash inspiration, the organisers hope, for visitors to encourage bioersity in their own gardens.The scheme sees gardens open to visitors at certain times throughout the year or by appointment, and includes  which will open for the first time ndash among them social support charity The Preshal Trustrsquos Govan garden.Some seem to defy the odds: at the most northerly garden, Norby at Burnside in Sandness, Shetland, Chinese tree peonies, shrub roses, lilies, hellebores, and grasses fromNew Zealand thrive despite the exposed landscape.And at Leathad Ard, Upper Carloway on Lewis, the owners refused to be deterred by the westerly winds, challenging hillside setting and surrounding peat bog to create a garden of colourful herbaceous borders, exposed beds packed with delicate blooms, fruit orchards, and vegetable patches.The scheme asks visitors to pay a small fee to visit each garden which then goes towards a range of charities, infor a look at often hidden back gardens and private woodlands where wildle thrive, and snowdrops and bluebells carpet the floor.Visitors who make an appointment to visit  Burnton Road in Dalrymple will step from a typical Ayrshire street tino a tropical haven. ldquoThe garden was fairly awful when we moved here, says David Blatchford, who since  has transformed the triangular corner plot into a welcoming jungle.ldquoBack then it was just a lawn, a gigantic leylandii, ivy and a crumbling shed.While that may sound like most Scottish gardens, David and his we Margaret planned ahead and brought favourite tree ferns and bamboo from their former property to plant.With the leylandii, ivy and shed gone, they created raised beds to tackle the dearth of topsoil and laid a serpentine path which now meanders through the dense, lush foliage, past giant, glossy leaves and towering palms.Bonsai and potted terrestrial ferns including rare blechnum species and succulents rest on the patio. Outside, hardy and tender bromeliads and aroids share space with lilies, cannas, gingers and bursts of Mexicanfeather grass.At the front of the garden, dahlias and a Chinese imported buddleia bring bursts of colour and dozens of red admiral butterflies.ldquoWe do have time to sit in the garden and enjoy it, he adds. ldquoAnd we do have a washing line ndash you just donrsquot see it hidden behind the bamboo.Around three hoursrsquo drive away, at Barochreal in Kilninver near Oban, a remarkable -year labour of love has seen its hard-working owners, Nigel and Antoinette Mitchell, scrape and shovel scrub grass and old sheep pens into a colourful haven.The pretty garden which hugs their white-walled, two-storey home buzzes with bees from their hives.A wild garden and rockery complement a rose garden created from a former sheep fank while raised beds have been made using stone left behind when the old dairy was taken down. Further on, their  acres extend to a waterfall and a small glen where  species of moth and more than  species of wildflowers thrive, including three types of wild orchid, and red squirrels and pine martens make their home.ldquoItrsquos slowly evolved, says Antoinette. ldquoAs one thing is done, another comes up. It takes all our energy to keep it going. Whenever therersquos nice weather, instead of enjoying it, wersquore working in it.The garden is so impressive that coach parties often roll in for a look. ldquoThey start coming at the end of April. The hardy plant people and the rhododendron people. People staying in ious hotels will phone up and ask to come.Many gardens have embracedldquowild elements to boost falling numbers of pollinators.At Baile Geamhraidh on the island of Lismore in the Inner Hebrides, a biodynamic farm encourages wildflowers, birds, bees and butterflies. Created from a field, the garden reflects the ecclesiastical history of the island, and includes a vegetable garden, a tree nursery, a physic garden and orchard.It is framed by standing stones, meadows and mountains, while rare breed Shetland horned cattle roam.Meanwhile, Bruckills Croft in Inverurie, Aberdeenshire, home of award-winning wildle gardener Helen Rushton, has a butterfly alley, wildflower meadow and pond.Other gardens have touching stories behind them. Angusrsquos Garden at Barguillean Farm in Glen Lonan, near Oban, was created as a motherrsquos tribute to her son who was killed while working in Cyprus in .Almost  gardens will open for snowdrop and winter walks throughout February and March, includingKailzie Gardens near Peebles and Ecclesgreig Castle outside Montrose, where there are more than  ieties of snowdrop.Over  charities will benefit from the scheme, while organisers hope gardens will inspire visitors to incorporate ideas and wildle features in their own gardens.Terrill Dobson, national organiser for Scotlandrsquos Gardens Scheme, says: ldquoOur gardens and green spaces are ecosystems that nurture a vast array of bioersity including insects, butterflies, birds, small animals, earthworms and even beneficial bacteria.ldquoAnd these in turn benefit our gardens, through pollination, improved structure and pest control, just to name a few.ldquoWersquore hoping people will walk away inspired by what theyrsquove seen.

title: scottish-wildcats-kittens-future-species-shoulders
story: Somewhere between the polar bear, the Bactrian camel and the Japanese macaque, Felis silvestris, among the rarest of them all, is usually found hiding behind a cairn, up a tree or curled up in a ball, snoozing.At noon most days, however, visitors to the Highland Wildle Park at Kincraig near Aviemore will be treated to a fleeting glimpse of its bushy tail, mean green-yellow eyes and thick fur, as one of the nationrsquos most elusive creatures emerges to snatch a lump of meat for lunch before retreating to the shadows.For most park visitors, that brief glimpse of the Scottish wildcats is at the top of their list of must-see attractions, possibly alongside Hamish the juvenile polar bear, a national treasure and the first cub born in the UK for  years, and the Amur tiger.What they wonrsquot see, however, is a massive behind-the-scenes effort spanning the UK and Europe, and which itrsquos hoped will throw a leline to ensuring Scottish wildcats ndash  times more endangered than the giant panda ndash will not just be around for generations to come, but could eventually become established in locations right across Scotland.Tucked out of sight on a patch of the Royal Zoological Society of Scotlandrsquos park which is out of bounds to visitors, a new wildcat reintroduction centre is about to become "ground zero" for the survival of a fragile species entwined in Scottish national identity but currently in a fierce catfight for its very survival.A combination of cross-breeding with feral and domestic cats, habitat loss, road accidents, historic persecution and disease has all but wiped out the purest of Scotlandrsquos treasured wildcat population.Left to their own devices, the tiny number with genes not already severely diluted from mating with outsiders, will dwindle, fade and disappear.Hopes are now pinned on a pound. million scheme led by the Royal Zoological Society of Scotlandand, almost certainly, some amorous intervention from the speciesrsquo closest European cousins to help the Scottish wildcat get back on its feet.By the end of this year, the first wildcats will be in settled in at the new reintroduction centre,  breeding pairs which ndash assuming nature takes it course ndash should produce enough healthy offspring to see  wildcats reintroduced to carefully picked spots in the Cairngorms over a three-year period.Eventually itrsquos hoped they could be reintroduced where in Scotland ndash raising the possibility of the creatures becoming commonplace across the country.Although, according to David Barclay, cat conservation project officer with the RZSS who currently oversees the  wildcats in the UK-wide breeding programme, the first challenge is to save the handful of remaining Scottish wildcats from extinction.ldquoTherersquos perhaps a very small number of wildcats left in Scotland, he admits. ldquoAnd we have a lot of evidence that says the population is non-viable.ldquoWithout putting more wildcats back, they will almost certainly go extinct in the next few years.ldquoWildcats are in that short list of animals that are iconic species for Scotland, such as the golden eagle and the red squirrel, he adds.ldquoFor Scotland not to have wildcats would be a very sad day.At Kincraig, a recent pound.million EU LIFE grant added to funding from the Garfield Weston Foundation, the National Trust for Scotland, the Peoplersquos Trust for Endangered Species and the European Nature Trust, has enabled work to start on building the new centre.A recruitment drive is now under way to find  staff while plans are being drawn up for a major campaign to encourage domestic cat owners to neuter their pets to avoid the main threat to wildcatsrsquo future, hybridisation.Feral or domestic cats that enter the wildcat reserve will be trapped, neutered, vaccinated and released.Most of the  breeding pairs are expected to be sourced mainly from the UK-wide wildcat breeding programme but some are likely to make the journey from Europe, in particular Spain, where wildcats have been found to share physical similarities to their Scottish relations, and populations are more stable.It may sound like a further erosion of the Scottish wildcatsrsquo precious gene pool, however Mr Barclay insists the European presence will strengthen, not weaken, the wildcatsrsquo chances of survival.ldquoThe European wildcats will improve the gene pool, he states. ldquoThe cat we have is a European wildcat, itrsquos just a dferent population thatrsquos more critically endangered.ldquoIf we have to bring some cats from Europe ndash and it would be a relatively small number ndash we would want to bring them from a population where we feel that there are similarities with Scottish cat.ldquoAnd Spanish wildcats look very similar to Scottish wildcats.ldquoIf you bring wildcats from Europe, you are bringing new genetic material which gives Scottish wildcats a boost in terms of the gene pool.The fight to save Scotlandrsquos wildcats has already crossed international boundaries: as well as working with Scottish Natural Heritage, the Cairngorms National Park Authority and Forestry and Land Scotland, the RSZZ Saving Wildcats project ndash the only official wildcats project in the country ndash is partnered with Swedish wildle park Nordenrsquos Ark, and Spainrsquos Junta De Andaluciacutea, which led the successful recovery of the Iberian lynx.It has been boosted by the arrival of two potential "Adam and Eve" wildcats: male and female, both accidentally trapped, both found to have surprisingly strong wildcat genes.While the male is now at an English zoo where itrsquos hoped nature will soon play its part in boosting wildcat numbers, the female, Lossie, has already produced five kittens from two litters.Last year, one of her offspring, Katrine, delivered her first litter ndash four kittens, each carrying on its tiny shoulders the future of a species which has roamed Scotlandrsquos hills since the Ice Age.ldquoFor next few years itrsquos about getting all the right tools in one place so we can create a viable, sustainable population of wildcats in one location, adds Mr Barclay.ldquoOnce we have been through that process and know that the reintroduction technology works, then we can replicate that across Scotland.ldquoThe crucial element is controlling the threat: we canrsquot release them until the threat is removed, and one of the biggest threats in hybrid and domestic cats.The reintroduction of wildcats would follow in the wake of the reintroduction of sea eagles, water voles and beavers to the wild ndash each native to Scotland but brought to extinction through hunting and loss of habitat.The wildcatsrsquocould also pave the way for other animals including lynx and wolves. Campaign group Rewilding Britain has also suggested the reintroduction of long-gone species including the dalmatian pelican, bison, boar and moose.Worryingly, however, are further signs that Scottish wildcats ndash and in some cases their European cousins ndash are hanging by the thinnest of threads.Last month an international genetic study of wildcats in  European countries published in the journal Conservation Genetics warned it had failed to identy a single pure wildcat in Scotland.Across Europe, wildcat numbers were also found to be affected by hybridisation, with the first example of a hybrid cat in the Eastern Alps of Austria.ldquoIn Scotland, we found exclusively hybrids of dferent classes, indicating hybridisation has been occurring for several generations, it states. ldquoAll samples from Scotland were identied as hybridshellip supporting previous findings that the genetic integrity of that wildcat population has been seriously compromised.It also presented a dire warning for the future of the species.ldquoFrequent hybridisation with the domestic cat may regionally threaten the genetic integrity of the European wildcat, as documented by the example of the wildcat in Scotland, it adds, ldquopotentially leading even to the genetic extinction of local populations.

title: scotlands-ferry-fiasco-tangled-web-operators-owners-works-theory-least
story: Victorian steamship tycoon David MacBrayne left his thriving business to his son and namesake in .Soon the fleet, connecting Glasgow to the isles and peninsulas of one of the worldrsquos longest coastlines, was to peak at  packet ships.It was never to be so big again, even more than century later.:Scottish ferries fiasco: competition watchdog issues stark warning to SNPOn the eve of the Great Depression, the MacBraynes sold out their family firm. Why  They had failed to raise the finance needed to upgrade their vessels and retain what had become essential for running leline ferry services: subsidies.That was . In those days state aid came by way of lucrative contracts to carry the post.Scroll forward  years and the issues are the same.How best to put Government money into ferries  And how to keep services going when that public funding ndash and fares ndash does not prove enough to provide a modern, reliable fleet and port infrastructure Add in European Union rules on state aid ndash or at least Scottish interpretation of those rules ndash and the result is an alphabet spaghetti of businesses and institutions.The row over a contract for two new high-tech ferries ndash with the public purse looking at a potential nine-figure loss ndash suddenly thrusts some of these bodies in to the limelight.So who are old man MacBraynersquos successors For most Scots, ferries, in the west at least, are synonymous with CalMac . This, after all, was how Scotlandrsquos nationalised ferry company was colloquially known.Now, a company called CalMac Ferries Limited, or CML, still operates most ferries on Clyde and Hebridean routes. It is based out of Gourock ferry terminal and is owned by a business called David MacBrayne Limited or DML, which is wholly owned by the Scottish Government.CML operates  vessels and  harbours, almost of all of which are owned by another body with an almost identical acronym, CMAL.This is Caledonian Maritime Assets Limited. CMAL, rather than CML, is the direct corporate successor of the old Caledonian MacBrayne company and it officially lists its foundation as .:Scotlands ferry fiasco: meet the eight people who run CMALIn effect, CMAL owns most of Scotlandrsquos ferries ndash including three operated by private company Sercoon subsidised routes to and from Orkney and Shetland ndash and many of the nationrsquos ferry ports. Like CML, CMAL is owned by the Scottish Government.This has been how ferries have been run in Scotland since the last year of the old Scottish Executive. CML has secured successive franchisesto run services using CMAL assets. Both CMAL and CML are companies, owned by the Government, not Government departments.CMAL, using Government money, has been responsible for investing in ports and procuring vessels. The theory  That this arrangement ndash rather like in the railways ndash allows a free market of sorts. The reality  Ultimately, it is the taxpayer who owns, runs, subsidises ndash and now builds ndash the ferries.In the saga of the purchase of the two now massively overdue and over budget new ships, it is CMAL that has come under fire.The companyrsquos HQ is in Port Glasgowrsquos historic town buildings, less than a -minute stroll from the shipyard where the hulks of two botched ferries, the Glen Sannox and the unnamed Hull , lie rusting.The yard ndash Ferguson Marine Engineering Limited or FMEL world of ferries ndash is now also owned by the Scottish Government after it was nationalised following the failure of the contract.The yard had been bought ndash rescued, it was reported ndash by tax exile Jim McColl.An independent report by FMEL after its Government takeover painted a picture of amateurish mismanagement at the yard before nationalisation, including basic failures to keep track of stock and clean-up.However, supporters of McColl have long briefed against CMAL and its executives. Last week, the businessman took aim at his one-time customers again. His point: they should not exist at all.ldquoWe donrsquot need CMAL to be there, the businessman told MSPs investigating how his contract had failed. ldquoBefore, it worked perfectly well with CalMac. It is surplus to requirements.McColl said CMAL executives had been civil in person but described a relationship which, via email, became testier. The businessman blames changes to spec on the boats he built from CMAL. The old CalMac, he said, ldquoknew what they wanted. His implication  CMAL does not.CMAL chief executive Kevin Hobbs will get his chance to speak later. He believes MSPs have heard ldquoserious inaccuracies.Opposition leaders see the debacle around McCollrsquos yardrsquos delivery of the two ferries as a political scandal. But will the fallout raise questions about the complex state-owned structures of CML DML CMAL FMEL operating, owning and building ships Or are Scotlandrsquos ferries doomed to face heavy seas regardless of how they are organised, as all of David MacBraynersquos successors have found

title: scotlands-ferry-fiasco-meet-eight-people-run-cmal
story: The companyrsquos leaders come, largely, from the private sector and have experience in both ships and ports.Chief executive Kevin Hobbs has run the business since  after a background managing a major port ndash the giant Milford Haven terminal in Wales ndash but his bio stresses he has experience managing vessels too.Chairman Erik Oslashstergaard has been in post since CMAL split from CML back in . He is a Danish shipping and transport veteran.CMALs director of vessels, Jim Anderson, is a fellow of the Royal Institution of Naval Architects and worked in senior management roles for shipbuilders, ship owners and design consultants.The companys finance director, Gillian Bruton, is an accountant who cut her teeth at PwC before serving in a senior role at Polaroid. Her job is shared with another major state-owned transport company, Highlands and Islands Airport, HIAL.Ramsay Muirhead is CMALs head of port infrastructure and planning. He is newly appointed to this post after  years at the company maintaining its harbours.CMAL also has three non-executive directors.Morag McNeil is a corporate lawyer whose past includes a spell as counsel to Forth Ports, one of Scotlands biggest harbour firms.Paul Croucher is a banker who has served in senior posts at several financial institutions and currently represents shareholders on the board of the Isle of Man Steam Packet Company.Lastly Graeme Woods is a marine engineer with  years experience in managing vessels and oil and gas operations as well as companies ranging from family firms to multinationals.

title: scottish-independence-government-launch-cinema-ad-campaign-boost-support-union
story: The Scotsman reports that thecampaign will include cinema adverts as well as billboards, radio, print adverts and social media posts in a bid to bolster support for the Union. it will set out tohighlight success in areas such as sport, culture and more that the UK have achieved together.:Scottish independence support maintains lead in latest pollAlthough thecampaign is in its early stages, reports suggest that as much as poundm could be ploughed into the showreel for the Union.The aims of the campaign are to match the impact of recent SNP videos widely shared on social media.A Scottish Tory source said that the party faced a battle to convince voters of the risk of giving the SNP another term in office in  saying: ldquoThe risk is that people think itrsquos OK to vote SNP eventheyrsquore calling for indyref, because Boris will stop it, Wersquore going to have to raise the stakes.: New poll on Scottish independence puts Yes aheadldquoWersquove learned a lot from the general election campaign, they added. ldquoIt will be gloves off in .The last poll on Scottish independence, fromPanelbase put Yes support at % - up five percentage points from a previous study.The poll commissioned by the Scot Goes Pop blog with the help of a crowdfunder and conducted between January  and , also says that pro-independence parties are on course to take % of the seats at Holyrood at next years elections.

title: snp-deputy-leader-very-difficult-see-derek-mackay-can-continue-msp
story: Keith Brown said politicians across Holyrood were shocked by Mr Mackays behaviour.He said he had not had any contact with the former minister since his resignation and suspension from the SNP.Mr Mackay sent some  messages to a -year-old boy over six months, including telling him he was cute and askingthe chats were "between us".Other messages offered to take the youngsterfor dinner and to a rugby match.They continued even after the teenager said he was still in school and then later said he was .The messages were published by the Scottish Sun and emerged just hours before Mr Mackay was due to deliver Scotlands pound billion Draft Budget.:Analysis: Does Derek Mackay scandal mark the beginning of the end for the SNP He resigned as finance secretary during a face-to-face meeting with Nicola Sturgeon on Wednesday night and was later suspended from the SNP.Appearing on the BBCs Politics Scotland, Mr Brown was asked whether Mr Mackay should continue as an MSP.He said: "I think its very dficult to see how he can continue, but it is his decision."Askedhe had ever had concerns about Mr Mackay, he said: "No. I wasnt aware of his text habits,you like, and this communicating with people of that age ndash completely unaware of that and it came as a shock to people throughout the party.:Teenager at centre of Derek Mackay scandal speaks to police"You could see the shock on people, not just the SNP but other parties as well."

title: joanna-cherry-says-pm-must-put-notice-indyref2
story: While First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has shied away from holding a consultative referendum, Joanna Cherry QC insisted that ldquonow is the moment to begin the preparations.She said on Twitter: ldquoBoris Johnson should be put on notice that we have options  we are not afraid to push forward.:Scottish independence: Government to launch cinema ad campaign to boost support for UnionThe SNP home affairs spokeswoman at Westminster suggested Holyrood should passa Bill to hold a consultative referendum, and then let the PM mount a legal challenge on whether they had the power to do so.However I also agree that ldquohellipnow is the moment to begin the preparations. To tell Johnson ldquosee you in courthe continues to block Scotlandrsquos demand for #Indyref. #scotlandsrighttochoosemdash Joanna Cherry QCFebruary , Such a case would be decided at the UK Supreme Court, with Ms Cherry stating: ldquoMany legal experts think we would win the argument.Setting out her case on Twitter she said ldquonow is the moment to begin the preparations. To tell Johnson ldquosee you in courthe continues to block Scotlandrsquos demand for #IndyrefPrime.She spoke out as a poll showed a majority of Scots were in favour of Holyrood legislating to hold a referendum,Westminster continues to block demands for a vote on the continuation of the Union.The Panelbase survey asked people for their views on what should happenthe UK Government continues to refuse to give permission for an independence vote ndash askingthe Scottish Parliament should legislate for such a ballot and then allow the courts to decideit could go ahead.Of thosewho expressed an opinion, % agreed with such an approach, with % opposed.Ms Cherry, who was involved in the successful legal challenge to the PM which last year saw the prorogation of Parliament ruled as unlawful, argued that taking this stance could ldquomove us away from the current impasse ndash which has seen both Theresa May and Boris Johnson refuse requests from the First Minister for Holyrood to be given the powers to hold a referendum.:Analysis: Does Derek Mackay scandal mark the beginning of the end for the SNP She stated: ldquoI believe that Holyrood passing a Bill to hold a referendum could be part of a multi-faceted strategy to move us away from the current impasse  stop the constant and unproductive talk about Section  orders  seeking ldquopermission to act from Westminster.ldquoThe balance of legal opinion is that we might well win any court challenge  I donrsquot believe that losing would set us back any further than where we are just now.Ms Sturgeoninsisted she would not sanction a ldquowildcat unauthorised referendum, as was held in Catalonia, when she set out her ldquonext steps towards independence at the end of January.However, she said then that there could come a time when the Scottish Government would consider holding a consultative vote ndashthis was ruled to be legal by the courts.

title: andrew-marr-show-ridge-sunday-review
story: The most infamous example of ldquoputting a kilt on it is usually held to be the Press  Journalrsquos reporting of the Titanic disaster under the headline, ldquoAberdeen man drowns at sea. The tale is not strictly accurate, however. On the first day of coverage there was no mention of Aberdeen on the next there was a subheading, ldquoAberdeen people on the Titanic, but it was some way down the page. Still, the legend persists.Over the years, the Scottish media as a whole has become adept at putting a kilt on items when required. Occasionally, London-based political programmes have a chance tothe compliment and feature Scottish stories, but they rarely do.Yesterday was a prime example. As you may have noticed, there was a big story in Scotland last week. Finance Secretary, text messages scandal, having to resign on day of his budget, ring a bell  While one did not expect The Andrew Marr Show and Sky Newsrsquo Ridge on Sunday to take the Derek Mackay story and go wall to wall with it, the subject was surely worth a stand-alone interview.: Beginning of the end for SNP Instead, the line-up on Marr was Liu Xiamoing, the Chinese ambassador to the UK, Dr Rosena Allin-Khan, who is standing for the deputy leadership of Labour, and Justice Secretary Robert Buckland. Sophy Ridge, meanwhile, spoke to Andy Burnham, the mayor of Manchester, Dawn Butler MP, another Labour deputy leadership candidate, former Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt, and the Housing Secretary Robert Jenrick.Of the two line-ups, perhaps only Ambassador Liu was of direct relevance to viewers in Scotland. Given the threat from coronavirus, what the Chinese Government has to say is of vital importance to everyone on the planet. ldquoWe believe the virus is controllable, preventable, curable, said the ambassador.Nor did Scotland come up in the paper review on Marr. No surprise there, since the Scottish Sunday newspapers do not feature unless the programme has decamped north. Yet Broadcasting House, in many ways the Radio  equivalent of Marrrsquos show, makes a point of inviting Scottish paper reviewers on to the programme now and then, and encourages them to talk about stories from their patch. How dficult would it be for the Marr team to set up a link to Scotland, or Wales and Northern Ireland, to find out what stories are making the headlines in the rest of the UK Perhaps in the case of Marr the thinking was to leave the Mackay story to Sunday Politics Scotland. It was the first topic in host Gordon Brewerrsquos review of the week with Jenni Davidson of Holyrood magazine and Peter Geoghegan, investigative journalist with the website openDemocracy.The main interview was a pre-recorded sit down between Brewer and Keith Brown, Depute Leader of the SNP. The news line from this was Mr Brown, at the third time of asking, saying it was very dficult to see how Derek Mackay could continue as an MSP.: Keith Brown interviewTalk eventually turned to the budget. Some % of people in Scotland were now paying more tax, said Brewer. According to SPICE, Holyroodrsquos research arm, he went on, the Scottish Government raised poundm more than it wouldit stuck with the UK policy. But when the block grant adjustment was taken into account the Scottish Government ended up with just poundm more.ldquoPeople in Scotland might be prepared to pay more taxthey thought the money was going somewhere useful, said Brewer.Brown said the money was going somewhere useful, public services, and that the majority of people in Scotland paid less tax than they would in the rest of the UK. ldquoScotlandrsquos got the lowest tax rate in the whole of the UK," he said.Mr Brown, a former Cabinet Secretary for the economy, did not move off the front foot. It was a robust ding-dong, as it should have been, ending with a challenge from Mr Brown when the looming shortfall in tax receipts was brought up.: Put PM on notice on indyrefldquoLook at the whole context in which we have this budget, said the constituency MSP for Clackmannanshire and Dunblane. ldquoI asked you on this programme a year or so ago why you never interview UK finance ministers hellipBrewer interrupted to promptly invite Chancellor Sajid Javid on to the show. ldquoIf hersquos watching, happy to interview him.Why donrsquot UK Ministers come on to Scottish television as a matter of course  You could argue it was not constitutionally polite to ask London-based Ministers when there are opposition politicians here who could step in. Yet such niceties do not stop Ministers commenting regularly on Scottish matters in the Commons. Boris Johnson, indeed, has made it a regular feature of Prime Ministerrsquos Questions.Given the Cabinet boycott of the Today programme and Good Morning Britain, andMr Johnson is as keen on being the Minister for the Union as he says, Number Ten might even welcome sending ministers outside London. Gordon Brewer and Boris Johnson: how about it

title: end-road-lollipop-men-women-scotland
story: Lollipop men and women were first introduced in London to enable policemen, who had previously run patrols, to perform other duties.Now it is feared they are fast becoming a relic of the past as their numbers slump, with campaigners fearing it is compromising the safety of children.New figures show that one in six lollipop men and women have been axed over eight years in Scotland.Some  school crossing patrol personnel have disappeared in Scotland between   and   as councils across the country have felt the financial pinch, according to data produce by the GMB union.During the summer, Moray Council became the first of Scotlands  local authorities to completely scrap its school crossing patrols, as part of a programme of savings.:What does it feel like to be a lollipop man Cutting all  lollipop men and women posts was aimed atto shave pound, off its spending.School crossing patrol officer, lollipop man of the year, Albert Mayfield, UK, th January . .And it meant that from June ,  almost , school pupils in the area had to navigate busy roads without the help of patrol officers.The councils online message to parents confirming the budget decision states: "Parents are reminded that they are responsible for ensuring their childs safety on their whole journey to and from school."Joshua Harris, director of campaigns for Brake, the road safety charity called for greater safety measures to protect children going to school.ldquoLollipop people provide a vital service, helping children cross roads safely on their way to school and offering a friendly face that encourages walking and cycling," he said. "Cuts to council funding are impacting on the safety of our roads and the loss of lollipop people is a troubling sign of this trend. The safety of children should not be compromised and we need to see more investment in safe routes to school, with mph speed limits and safe segregated space to walk and cycle.Details of the Scottish cuts have come as the GMB union warned that Great Britain has lost more than , lollipop men and women during the eight years.In a survey of local authorities, the union found that in   there were , employed by councils across England, Scotland and Wales and by   that had dipped to just , ndash a drop of ,.In Scotland there were  school patrol officers in   down from  eight year previously but the level of cuts has not been as sharp as has been felt in other parts of Britain.Rehana Azam, GMB national secretary said: ldquoTen years of brutal Tory austerity have left scars right across our society - and now its got to the point where our kids arent even safe walking home from school.:What does it feel like to be a lollipop man "No parent wants to get the call that their child has been involved in an accident, but thats the risk councils are taking because they are so cash-strapped.Seventy-four-year-old Nkosana Mdikane ofDumbarton was banned from dancing with his giant lollipop and giving school kids high fives last year"Austerity is a choice but councils have been left with no choice but to make savings."Our public services need proper funding, so they can rebuild from the ruins left by a decade of savage cuts."Official figures show that the number of children injured while out walking in Scotland has more than halved over the same period. In  there were  child pedestrian casualties, while in  there were .But Sustrans - which promotes safe walking and cycling networks across the UK - has previously indicated that this may be because the number of children walking to school has fallen dramatically. It has been campaigning for children to walk or cycle to reduce congestion and pollution around the school gates saying it will also help their mental and physical health.Nearly half of children they surveyed in  wanted to cycle to school but only four in  were allowed to.Meanwhile by  it is predicted that % of girls and % of boys will be overweight or obese, while Sustrans says that a short walk each day is easy, free and good for the health.Although accident rates are falling, more child and adult pedestrians are injured in road traffic accidents in deprived areas compared with more affluent areas.Mary Hunt made history when she became Britainrsquos firstlollipop lady on  September, . But at the time she was a one-off, as the Second World War put paid to a nationwide scheme.It was not until May  that lollipop ladies, or crossing patrols as they are now known, first had their powers to stop traffic enshrined in the School Crossing Patrol Act.The earliest lollipops were red and black rectangles, with "Stop, Children Crossing" printed on them.The round lollipop seen today was introduced in the s while in  the unorm changed to the familiar yellow coat.The lollipop man term was first coined by ventriloquist John Bouchier, who visited schools nationwide with his dummy Charlie to promote the scheme.In , a change in the law gave responsibility for patrols to councils and removed the legal requirement to provide them.Under UK law it is an offence for a motorist not to stop when signalled to do so by a patroller. The Transport Act  changed the law so that a patroller had the authority to stop the traffic for any pedestrian.

title: Marianne Taylor  Why the Tories are right about free speech
story: In a recent newspaper article the UK Education Secretary was impressively straightforward about his intentions:universities in England donrsquot do more to defend and safeguard free speech, the Government will.It seems strange and discombobulating that such a fundamental right, which is already etched in law, needs to be restated or protected, especially in our institutions of learning and research. After all, what are universities fornot to debate, scrutinise and test old, current and new ways of thinking :Ian McConnell: Brexitersrsquo antics miss the point as reality tells a dferent storyBut the chilling frequency and virulence of recent campaigns by students and activists seeking to completely shut down conversations around certain issues highlights the pressing need for action.And wersquore not just talking any more about the no-ing of ldquooffensive thinkers and speakers at university union events. Over the last months around the UK wersquove seen increasing numbers of protests and petitions against members of teaching staff who are accused of holding offensive, upsetting and inappropriate views, accompanied by calls for them to be silenced or even sacked.There have also been calls for entire areas of teaching and academic research to be withdrawn or have funding removed, for conferences to be cancelled, all because students deem them too upsetting and offensive. University managers have sometimes been too quick to bow to pressure, highlighting societyrsquos increasing confusion and lack of confidence in dealing with issues of free speech.Granted, the debates at the centre of current brouhahas are complex and controversial: Israel and Palestine, gender identity and womenrsquos rights. They are also very important. But not as important as the wider need to protect our right to talk about them. Evenyou couldnrsquot give a monkeys about the Gender Recognition Act, the things you care passionately about could be next on the list of views deemed offensive. You, too, could be cancelled.How could it have come to this  How could folk, especially younger folk, be so easily and willingly prepared to give away their own freedoms  Why donrsquot they relish countering arguments they disagree with rather than silencing them Social media has much to answer for, of course, not least the silos and bubbles many of us spend our digital lives in, the echo chambers that reflect our own views right back, the need for every issue to be black or white. When opposing views appear, they immediately seem shocking. Frustration ensues. Then anger. Then offence. Then hysteria.:Letters: Getting the EU out of the way will aid independenceSuch behaviour all too easily carries dangerously into real le. How long before itrsquos wired into our DNA Itrsquos interesting that the Tories that have taken up the cause of free speech at universities. Has there been a swing towards right-wing libertarianism  Could it be to take the pressure off Boris Johnson over racist, sexist and homophobic comments he has made in the past  Both seem plausible.Regardless of the reasoning, I welcome the action, which serves us all well in the end, especially with Labour and the SNP tied in knots over anti-semitism and trans rights, rather than focusing on the wider implications of these debates for free speech.Mr Williamson is being clear and sensible. If universities donrsquot adopt strong codes of conduct that champion academic freedom and free speech while ldquoexplicitly recognising that this may sometimes cause offence, the Government will change the legal framework to strengthen free speech and clary the duties of institutions such as student unions.I would like to see the Scottish Government follow this lead. Guidance currently exists for Scottish universities, produced by the Equality and Human Rights Commission, but recent events - not least the extreme reaction to discussion of gender identity and its impact on womenrsquos rights - suggest it is not working.Any focus on free speech is a reminder to all that while feeling offended is real and unpleasant, it is merely that: a feeling. Yes, feelings matter. But they donrsquot give anyone an automatic legal right to silence someone .If maturity means agreeing with something that is said, even when you donrsquot particularly like the person saying it, it also means accepting that the world is full of views you disagree with. Especiallyyou spend most of your le on social media. Some of it will be abhorrent and horrible, insulting and offensive. But that doesnrsquot mean it cannot be said at all.

title: andrew-mckie-uk-cant-afford-kicked-around-us
story: Those thoughts were prompted by the case of Anne Sacoolas, the we of an American diplomat who killed a young man called Harry Dunn with her car in Northamptonshire, then left for the US, and refuses toto face trial. The fact that she isnrsquot facing a court made it impossible to judge that issue, so instead I asked why the same offence ndash in this case, allegedly careless or reckless driving ndash should receive minor penalties when no harm ensues, and potentially a very serious one , when the worst happens.The conclusion must be that the law is pragmatic and worldly, rather than dealing with abstract ethical questions. The moral issue raised by careless driving is the same whether or not therersquos an accident, but real-world effects are hugely dferent. Butwe accept this compromise ndash and the very existence of diplomatic immunity is an example of putting practical interests above pure justice ndash wersquore at least entitled to an explanation of why the normal rule of law is being set aside.The allegation that Mrs Sacoolas is not only the we of an American diplomat, but herself a CIA agent, doesnrsquot change this basic dilemma but,true, goes some way to explaining why this should have been a thorny case in terms of Realpolitik and international relations. The case of Mike Lynch, a British businessman who is to be extradited to America on fraud charges, is a further example of what looks like political expediency winning out over justice.In , the Crown Prosecution Service found no grounds for prosecuting Dr Lynch, who was running a UK company listed on the London Stock Exchange, governed by English law and UK accounting practices. A subsequent civil case has finished hearing evidence but not yet produced a ruling.Yet under the US UK extradition arrangements introduced by Tony Blairrsquos government in , the Home Secretary ldquomust process the request, and no appeal is possible. Americans, by contrast, get to challenge such requests from the UK in their own courts, or, in the case of Mrs Sacoolas, ignore them altogether.This not only seems obviously unjust, it isnrsquot even very pragmatic in political terms. Eventhe UKis less powerful than the US, it cannot be remotely in our interests to allow such one-sided agreements. There may be an argument, evenitrsquos not very moral one, for compromises for the sake of some supposed greater good. There isnrsquot for just being kicked around. It may be worth bearing this in mind as we attempt to negotiate a trade deal.

title: parasite-makes-oscars-history-best-picture-victory
story: The class satire by auteur Bong Joon-ho also won best director, best original screenplay and best international feature, leaving Sir Sam Mendes empty-handed.It was widely thought that the British filmmaker would win his second directing Oscar for the First World War epic, filmed to appear as one long take.It would have come exactly  years after his win for American Beauty but he was pipped to the post for the Academy Award by director Bong, despite success at both the Baftas and the Golden Globes.The South Korean filmmaker appeared stunned to win the directing prize, saying: ldquoAfter winning best international feature, I thought I was done for the day and ready to relax.He quoted Martin Scorsese, saying: ldquoWhen I was young and studying cinema, there was a saying that I carved deep into my heart, lsquoWhat is the most personal is the most creativersquo, and asked the audience to stand in honour of the veteran director.He added: ldquoI will drink until next morning. did enjoy success in the cinematography category, where Roger Deakins won his second Oscar in three years.It was also celebrated for sound mixing and visual effects.British hopefuls were shut out of the acting categories, with success for Joaquin Phoenix, Renee Zellweger, Laura Dern and Brad Pitt, but Sir Elton John did triumph in the original song category.He won alongside his long-time collaborator Bernie Taupin for their trackLove Me Again for biopic Rocketman.Pitt won his first acting Oscar for his supporting role in Once Upon A Timehellip In Hollywoodand took a swipe at the Senate and thanked his children.He previously won a best picture Oscar as the producer of  Years A Slave but this is his first acting prize.As he was handed his prize by Regina King, he criticised Senate Republicans for refusing to allow former national security adviser John Bolton to testy in US president Donald Trumprsquos impeachment trial.He said: ldquoThey tell me I have only got  seconds, that is  seconds more than the Senate gave John Bolton this week.ldquoIrsquom thinking maybe Quentin does a movie about it and in the end the adults do the right thing.Dern got an early birthday present as she won the best supporting actress Oscar for her role in Marriage Story.She will turn  at midnight in Los Angeles.Her mother, the actress Diane Ladd, wiped away tears as she watched her daughter collect her prize.Dern said: ldquoSome say never meet your heroes but I say,yoursquore really blessed, you get them as your parents.ldquoI share this with my acting legends, Diane Ladd and Bruce Dern. You got game, I love you.#Oscars Moment: @LauraDern wins Best Supporting Actress for @MarriageStory. pic gcnKoRMomdash The AcademyFebruary , Ladd was nominated for the best supporting actress prize three times but never won.Dern added: ldquoThank you all for this gt, this is the best birthday present ever.Phoenix won the leading actor prize for Joker and used his impassioned speech to talk about equality rights.He said: ldquoI think at times we feel or are made to feel that we champion dferent causes. But for me, I see commonality. I think, whether wersquore talking about gender inequality or racism or queer rights or indigenous rights or animal rights, wersquore talking about the fight against injustice.Phoenix became tearful at the end of the speech as he remembered his late brother, the actor River Phoenix, who died aged  in .He said: ldquoWhen he was , my brother wrote this lyric, lsquoRun to the rescue with love and peace will followrsquo.Zellweger paid tribute to Judy Garland as she was named best actress for her role as the Wizard Of Oz star in Judy.She said: ldquoAnd though Judy Garland did not receive this honour in her time, I am certain that this moment is an extension of the celebration of her legacy that began on our film set and is also representative of the fact that her legacy of unique exceptionalism and inclusivity and generosity of spirit.ldquoMiss Garland, you are certainly among the heroes who unite and define us and this is certainly for you. Irsquom so grateful.The Oscars ceremony, which did not have a host for the second year in a row, featured a surprise appearance from Eminem.The rapper performed his Oscar-winning song Lose Yourself,  years after he snubbed the ceremony.There was also a performance by Billie Eilish, who sang The Beatlesrsquo Yesterday during the In Memoriam segment.

title: winners-losers-oscars
story: Here is a look at the other winners and losers from the night.Good night for:ParasiteThe Korean film was the first from the country to be nominated for an Oscar, and ended up leaving with four ndash including the top prizes of best picture and best director.Toy Story Woody and Buzz Lightyear proved to be a winning combination once again, as the Pixar film scored the animation prize, despite not winning at the Baftas or Golden Globes.:lsquoParasitersquo makes Oscars history with best picture victoryHildur GuonadottirThe Icelandic composer won the Academy Award for her original score for Joker, making her the fourth woman in history to win in the Oscarsrsquo scoring categories, and the first since .Bad night forSir Sam Mendesrsquos First World War epic was widely expected to win the best director and best picture prizes, but was instead recognised for cinematography, visual effects and sound mixing.The IrishmanMartin Scorsesersquos widely-praised gangster drama came into the ceremony with  nominations, but walked away empty-handed.NetflixThe Irishman coming up short meant it was a disappointing night for the streaming service. title: bbc-scotland-step-security-news-crews-live-broadcasts
story: Action is being taken after a number of news crews reported being subjected to personal abuse from members of the public while on outside broadcasts.It is understood news crews, including some female staff, suffereda level of abuse which left them fearing for their safety.:Questions remain over anyto BBC duties for Michael Stewart after Rangers rantOn one occasion, a crew had to move location due to ongoing verbal abuse.Security was provided to staff at the time, but the BBC has now indicated it is likely to increase assistance for outside broadcasts.The action comes at a time when concern is mounting about the abuse journalists often face online.In addition to increasing security, the BBC has vowed to call-out future instances of abuse when they happen at events by reporting them to organisers.Staff were told about the action during a briefing at BBC Scotlandrsquos headquarters in Glasgow.:Over , sign petition calling for BBC to reinstate Michael StewartHead of newsgathering Howard Simpson told BBC staff: ldquoYou do a fantastic job out in the field but we know there have been instances recently when some of you have had dficult situations to deal with as you go about your job in telling our audiences whatrsquos happening.ldquoAs ever you deal with this really professionally ndash but be assured thatthese incidents happen while covering organised events in future, we will call it out with organisers so that we reduce the chances of it happening again.ldquoGiving our audience as much informationand as many facts as we can is crucial to what we dondash no matter how uncomfortable that is for some vocal minorities who would rather hear only what they want to hear.

title: nicola-sturgeon-facing-questions-derek-mackays-departure
story: Richard Leonard has written to the First Minister demanding to know why she opted to let Mr Mackay resign from her cabinet, rather than immediately dismissing him.He is also demanding that the SNP leader make public any phone records and or notes of any conversation she had with Mr Mackay after learning about his behaviour.:Mark Smith: Crisis  What crisis  The Derek Mackay scandal wonrsquot damage the SNP one little bitIn his letter to the First Minister Mr Leonard said: ldquoThe conduct that the Cabinet Secretary has admitted to would, in my view, merit a dismissal from office by the First Minister rather than allowing a resignation.The Scottish Labour leader has already condemned Mr Mackayrsquos ldquopredatory behaviour afterthe Scottish Sun reported he had sent  messages to a -year-oldwho he had befriended on Facebook and Instagram.The -year-old politician, who came out as gay in , is reported to have told the youngster he was ldquocute and offered to take him to a rugby game and out to dinner.Mr Leonard said it was ldquodeeply concerning that such a senior member of this parliament was not immediately dismissed by the First Minister.The Labour leader said: ldquoThe fact that his behaviour was directed towards a teenage schoolboy should have been enough for the First Minister to take decisive and fast action.He insisted: ldquoIt is now vital that the full circumstances leading to Derek Mackayrsquos resignation are revealed publicly.ldquoThe contact Nicola Sturgeon had with Mr Mackay after she was made aware of the allegations should be shared immediately.:Analysis: Does Derek Mackay scandal mark the beginning of the end for the SNP Meanwhile Liberal Democrat MSP Alex Cole-Hamilton wants the law to be changed so that all MSPs are required togo through the same background checks that someone working with children or vulnerable groups would have.He plans to bring forward amendments to the DisclosureBill when it is formally lodged, that would require elected politicians to be vetted by the Protecting Vulnerable Groupsscheme.Mr Cole-Hamilton insisted the change was not being proposed in response to any single incident ndash adding that he had been ldquoexploring this proposal for months.But he stated: ldquoI have always been conscious that with elected office comes a huge power imbalance. We know that people can use their status to manipulate, target and exploit. People need protecting from that and this needs to be done through law.The Liberal Democrat added: ldquoParties each have their own candidate approval processes, but none will offer the same level of protection as a PVG certicate.ldquoThe prospect and knowledge of this extra independent check will also serve the purpose of deterring people who would be inappropriate from standing for public office in the first place.He said MSPs could ldquooften have unsupervised contact with children or vulnerable adults, as he stressed: ldquoParents should know their children are in the presence of someone who can be trusted and has been checked up on.ldquoBut those assurances simply donrsquot exist at the moment, and thatrsquos wrong.Mr Mackay stepped down hours before he had been due to announce Holyroodrsquos budget for the coming year to MSPs, with public finance minister Kate Forbes standing in for him at the last minute.In his resignation statement heaccepted he had ldquobehaved foolishly and apologised unreservedly to the teenage boy involved and his family.A spokesman for the First Minister said: ldquoBoth the Scottish Government and SNP acted swtly, decisively and entirely appropriately when the details of this issue came to light.ldquoDerek Mackay is no longer a minister and he is suspended from both the SNP and the parliamentary group pending an investigation by the party.

title: last call to nature fund applicants
story: Nature enthusiasts are being encouraged to submit ambitious ideas to improve habitats, safeguard species and tackle the causes of bioersity loss.Applications are being invited for the latest round of the Bioersity Challenge Fund .But anyone applying will have to be quick – applications for this round must be received by midnight on Monday, February . The Bioersity Challenge Fundspecically encourages applicants with innovative projects that improve bioersity and address the impact of climate change, increasing the resilience of our most at-risk habitats and species and creating large areas of brand new or restored habitat.Environment Secretary Roseanna Cunningham said: “We all have a central role to play in combating bioersity loss and tackling the global climate emergency.“Bioersity loss and climate change are intimately bound together. Nature plays a key role in defining and regulating our climate and climate is key in shaping the state of nature.“People and communities who want to be at the forefront of pioneering work to restore our habitats, protect our species and promote nature can now apply for additional support through the Bioersity Challenge Fund.”Scottish Natural Heritage chief executive Francesca Osowska has been excited by the very high quality of applications received so far, and would love to hear even more bright ideas.“People know that climate change is a big issue but not as many know that bioersity loss is also a global and generational threat to human well-being,” she said. “Pollinators are a vital part of the building blocks of le on earth, and we need to support all of Scotland’s bioersity, from bees and butterflies to pondle and peatlands, because enriching our nature is also an important part of the solution to the climate emergency.“Nature is at the heart of what we do, and we will continue to deliver the transformational change needed to bring a nature-rich future for Scotland.”More information about the fund can be found at Bioersity Challenge Funddata-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.ellontimes webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The fire service is eager for us all to avoid the devastating consequences of white goods catching fire in our homes." title: brewdog ellon visitor centre plan approved
story: Plans to create a new bar and visitor centre in Ellon have been approved.Brewing giants BrewDog submitted plans to Aberdeenshire Council in November last year for the creation of a new bar and visitor centre next to its Ellon headquarters.The new bar and visitor centre will be located inside the existing building at Balmacassie Industrial Estate that previously belonged to Power Jacks.The brewing firm will change part of the unit from office accommodation and production space to a new ‘DogTap’ public house and visitor centre.BrewDog took ownership of the building in  after Power Jacks moved to Westhill. It was initially proposed that BrewDog would transform the building into ‘The DogHouse’ Hotel but the plan never came to fruition.The new proposal will see the relocation of the existing ‘DogTap’ bar which is “oversubscribed” and no longer suitable to meet customer demand.The new bar will also feature a ‘BottleDog’ retail area where customers can buy bottles of beer and other merchandise. As with the existing bar, food will continue to be served on the site.A dedicated events space and beer museum will be created to give visitors the chance to see how the brewing process works.External changes will be made to the existing site including the addition of an outdoor seating area and children’s play area.Aberdeenshire Council planners approved the plans stating that the proposal is “appropriate” for the site given and “is in keeping with the character of the wider area in that it provides s directly related and ancillary to neighbouring sites”.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.ellontimes webimage ..! image image.jpeg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Gillian Martin MSP with Ron MacDonald, Secretary of the Newburgh  Ythan Community Trust, at Ythan Estuary"  MSP welcomes Ythan Seal Viewing Project cash viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"

title: new appointment for inverurie orchestra
story: Inverurie Orchestra has welcomed Ignasi Sol# as its new Conductor and Music Director.The appointment comes following the departure of Dr Paul Tierney last year who led the -strong orchestra from its inception in .The Orchestra played its last concert with Dr Tierney before Christmas to a packed Acorn Centre delivering "The Snowman" to considerable acclaim.Dr Tierney is moving on to embrace other responsibilities and continues as Music Director at Haddo.Ignasi was born in Catalunya and began his cello studies at the age of  tutored by the cello disciples of Pablo Casals, Jacques Doué and Peter Thielemann.During his youth Ignasi won several prizes for young musicians.At the age of  he was accepted at the prestigious Liceu of Barcelona to study cello performance with the principal cello of the Spanish National Symphony Orchestra, Angel Luis Quintana.At the same time he took up a place as solo cello at the Young Opera of Catalonia. Alongside his cello studies, Ignasi studied conducting with the principal conductors of the Opera del Liceu and the National Symphony Orchestra of Catalunya. After finishing his degree, Ignasi began his cello master studies in the Netherlands with the disciple of Paul Tortelier, Herre-Jan Stegenga, and conducting studies with the former assistant to Valery Gergiev, Hans Leenders. During this time Ignasi was a student with both the Rotterdam Philharmonic and the National Wroclaw Symphony Orchestras.In , after finishing his master’s degree, Ignasi moved to Aberdeen to work with Sistema Scotland in Big Noise Torry to further improve his teaching and conducting skills.In October that year, he volunteered to be the assistant conductor of University of Aberdeen Symphony Orchestra and, in , became its Music Director, as well as the Music Director of the Marischal Chamber Orchestra.Inverurie Orchestra is looking forward to an exciting period of development under Ignasi in partnership with the orchestra’s recently appointed Leader, Aden Mazur.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Canine Partners is looking for parents to care for and train puppies." title: tesco scraps tinned multipacks in stores
story: Tesco stores in Ellon and Inverurie will replace plastic-wrapped multipacks with plastic-free multibuys on tinned food eliminating  tonnes of plastic from the environment.Tesco has announced it will become the first UK retailer to remove plastic-wrapped multipacks from all Tesco stores and replace them with plastic-free multibuys.This will see  million pieces of plastic eliminated. Tins will be available inidually, with no plastic wrap holding them together any more from March .They’ll still be eligible for multibuy deals, representing the same good value for customers, just without plastic.It is estimated some , tinned multipacks are bought every day at Tesco.More than % of Tesco customers include multipacks in their shop. Multipacks of baked beans, tuna, tinned tomatoes and soup are among the most frequently-bought grocery items in the UK. The change applies to both Tesco own brand products and branded products. It will help more than eight million households in the UK reduce the amount of plastic they use.It contributes to Tesco’s commitment to remove bn pieces of plastic from its own brand products by the end of . Tesco CEO Dave Lewis said, “We are removing all unnecessary and non-recyclable plastic from Tesco. “As part of this work, removing plastic wrapped multipacks from every Tesco store in the UK will cut  tonnes of plastic fromtheenvironment everyyear and customerswill still benefit from the same great value ‘multipack’ price. This is part of our plan to remove  billion pieces of plastic in .” data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.ellontimes webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The location of the new BrewDog bar and visitors centre"  BrewDog Ellon visitor centre plan approved viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"At the end of last year Tesco removed all hard to recycle materials from Tesco own brand products and is working with suppliers to do the same. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below.
